elements.content: <ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">During a single crystal structure determination some symmetry elements may go unrecognized. For example, the molecule reported in figure clearly shows a ternary axis that was lost during the X-ray study. The omission of symmetry elements (especially the centre of symmetry) results in poor molecular geometry, but sometimes more hidden errors (as false polymorphism) may be introduced. For these reasons, the structure results should be validated for missed higher symmetry before publication using appropriate programs as <ce:small-caps>MISSYM</ce:small-caps>, <ce:small-caps>CHECKCIF</ce:small-caps> or <ce:small-caps>PLATON</ce:small-caps>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
During a single crystal structure determination some symmetry elements may go unrecognized. For example, the molecule reported in figure clearly shows a ternary axis that was lost during the X-ray study. The omission of symmetry elements (especially the centre of symmetry) results in poor molecular geometry, but sometimes more hidden errors (as false polymorphism) may be introduced. For these reasons, the structure results should be validated for missed higher symmetry before publication using appropriate programs as MISSYM, CHECKCIF or PLATON.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">260 structures published in Inorganica Chimica Acta present some problem about their crystal and molecular symmetry, moreover 41 compounds have been already corrected in this journal or in other journals. The unavailability of the structure factors tables has prevented a complete correction, in fact, we have reached a definitive result only for 52 crystalline compounds. These are divided into five categories: (A) incorrect Laue Group (19 examples), (B) omission of a centre of symmetry (20 examples), (C) incorrect Laue group and omission of a centre of symmetry (one example) (D) omission of a centre of symmetry coupled with a failure to recognize systematic absences (10 examples) and finally (E) non-space group translations (two examples). Moreover, other 44 examples of non-space group translations might be present, but we have not reached a definitive result for the unavailability of the structure factor tables.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
260 structures published in Inorganica Chimica Acta present some problem about their crystal and molecular symmetry, moreover 41 compounds have been already corrected in this journal or in other journals. The unavailability of the structure factors tables has prevented a complete correction, in fact, we have reached a definitive result only for 52 crystalline compounds. These are divided into five categories: (A) incorrect Laue Group (19 examples), (B) omission of a centre of symmetry (20 examples), (C) incorrect Laue group and omission of a centre of symmetry (one example) (D) omission of a centre of symmetry coupled with a failure to recognize systematic absences (10 examples) and finally (E) non-space group translations (two examples). Moreover, other 44 examples of non-space group translations might be present, but we have not reached a definitive result for the unavailability of the structure factor tables.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The November 2003 release of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) version 5.25  contains structural details (unit-cell dimensions and atom coordinates) for 8466 distinct entries published in Inorganica Chimica Acta (hereafter ICA). 260 of these structures present some problems about their crystal and molecular symmetry, 41 have been already revised in ICA or in other journals<ce:footnote id="fn1">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>
<ce:note-para>Refcodes (alphabetically ordered) of the structures already corrected in ICA, introducing this Refcode in the CSD system the name of the compound, its figure and all the other information will be apparent on the screen: AETXCO, BIWHEU, CIDVOA, DACONI, DOFXIF, DUPFEZ10, FARNER, FARNIV, FEKQIV, FIWBIW, GADWEN, GADXAK, GALYOH, HEFSIU, HICMUB, JAHDIF, JAXBAL01, JUHWIS, JUNNAH, KISNAB, LOMZES, NALCIM, NARQUS, NEGXOM, NIJGIW, NOHNED, NOHNED01, PAKKER, POJKAA, POQRUI, QANXOS, SAZPEO, TOSSAV, VENCOG, WABKOZ, WABLIU, ZATGIK, ZAXWAW, ZEGRIM10, ZIYPUS, ZUFDIN.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote>
 and 52 structures are now revised to space groups of higher symmetry than originally reported. We report only two examples of non-space group translations (hereafter NSGT), but other 44 examples of NSGT might be present, but without the structure factors (S.F.) tables is impossible to reach any conclusive result.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The November 2003 release of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) version 5.25  contains structural details (unit-cell dimensions and atom coordinates) for 8466 distinct entries published in Inorganica Chimica Acta (hereafter ICA). 260 of these structures present some problems about their crystal and molecular symmetry, 41 have been already revised in ICA or in other journals
1
Refcodes (alphabetically ordered) of the structures already corrected in ICA, introducing this Refcode in the CSD system the name of the compound, its figure and all the other information will be apparent on the screen: AETXCO, BIWHEU, CIDVOA, DACONI, DOFXIF, DUPFEZ10, FARNER, FARNIV, FEKQIV, FIWBIW, GADWEN, GADXAK, GALYOH, HEFSIU, HICMUB, JAHDIF, JAXBAL01, JUHWIS, JUNNAH, KISNAB, LOMZES, NALCIM, NARQUS, NEGXOM, NIJGIW, NOHNED, NOHNED01, PAKKER, POJKAA, POQRUI, QANXOS, SAZPEO, TOSSAV, VENCOG, WABKOZ, WABLIU, ZATGIK, ZAXWAW, ZEGRIM10, ZIYPUS, ZUFDIN.

 and 52 structures are now revised to space groups of higher symmetry than originally reported. We report only two examples of non-space group translations (hereafter NSGT), but other 44 examples of NSGT might be present, but without the structure factors (S.F.) tables is impossible to reach any conclusive result.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Also for the other 123 (=260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>41<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>52) structures is not possible to reach any conclusive result for the same reason. We hope that these 167 (=123<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>44) structures will not remain for ever in this dubious condition.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Also for the other 123 (=260−41−44−52) structures is not possible to reach any conclusive result for the same reason. We hope that these 167 (=123+44) structures will not remain for ever in this dubious condition.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The unavailability of S.F. tables has produced several difficulties and we suggest to ICA to store these tables as electronic files which can be made conveniently accessible to the crystallographic community and other scientists.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The unavailability of S.F. tables has produced several difficulties and we suggest to ICA to store these tables as electronic files which can be made conveniently accessible to the crystallographic community and other scientists.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">However, even working only with atomic coordinates we will show that an incorrect space group produces not only poor molecular geometry but sometimes also other chemical errors as the discovery of false polymorphs or its contrary.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: However, even working only with atomic coordinates we will show that an incorrect space group produces not only poor molecular geometry but sometimes also other chemical errors as the discovery of false polymorphs or its contrary.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The percentage of possible revisions was evaluated by Baur and Tillmanns  to be about 3% of all the published structures (∼298<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>000 entries are reported in the CSD version 5.25, November 2003), so that up to 9000 structures may be incorrect. Since the number of corrected structures, including the present ones is 826 , there are still ca. 8000 structures that must be corrected. The percentage of incorrect structures reported in ICA should be at maximum 260/8466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.07%, a value close to the Baur and Tillmanns expectation, but at the moment the certain percentage is only 93/8466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.10%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The percentage of possible revisions was evaluated by Baur and Tillmanns  to be about 3% of all the published structures (∼298000 entries are reported in the CSD version 5.25, November 2003), so that up to 9000 structures may be incorrect. Since the number of corrected structures, including the present ones is 826 , there are still ca. 8000 structures that must be corrected. The percentage of incorrect structures reported in ICA should be at maximum 260/8466=3.07%, a value close to the Baur and Tillmanns expectation, but at the moment the certain percentage is only 93/8466=1.10%.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Data retrieval and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Throughout this paper, crystal structures will be referred to by six-letter (or six-letter<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>two-digit) Refcode assigned in the CSD. The coordinates were obtained from the above-mentioned 5.25 version of the CSD, which we follow for the numbering of the atoms. The reading will be more comfortable editing the CSD file and using the appropriate Refcodes, thus the numbering and the graphical scheme of the compounds will be apparent on the screen. The chemical identity of each compound can be found in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. We have used the same methods (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">shelx</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">laue</ce:inf>, etc.) and electronic programs (CLASS.FOR, CELL.FOR, FSCC.FOR, etc.) already described by us elsewhere . Moreover, we have also used the efficient program PLATON.EXE written by Spek .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Data retrieval and methods
Throughout this paper, crystal structures will be referred to by six-letter (or six-letter+two-digit) Refcode assigned in the CSD. The coordinates were obtained from the above-mentioned 5.25 version of the CSD, which we follow for the numbering of the atoms. The reading will be more comfortable editing the CSD file and using the appropriate Refcodes, thus the numbering and the graphical scheme of the compounds will be apparent on the screen. The chemical identity of each compound can be found in 
. We have used the same methods (R
shelx, R
laue, etc.) and electronic programs (CLASS.FOR, CELL.FOR, FSCC.FOR, etc.) already described by us elsewhere . Moreover, we have also used the efficient program PLATON.EXE written by Spek .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We define the shift necessary to achieve the higher symmetry as one half of the distance between the two atoms that became crystallographic equivalent after the space group change.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The new crystal systems are described following the conventions proposed by Mighell .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">One structure (ENCNBZ) has been revised using the structure factors taken directly from the original publication, but usually they are not reported in ICA. The unavailability of S.F. tables has led us to evaluate the correctness of the space group change by comparison of the revised bond lengths and angles with those normally accepted in literature. In particular the word “accepted” means reference to the tables of bond lengths reported in papers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
We define the shift necessary to achieve the higher symmetry as one half of the distance between the two atoms that became crystallographic equivalent after the space group change.
The new crystal systems are described following the conventions proposed by Mighell .
One structure (ENCNBZ) has been revised using the structure factors taken directly from the original publication, but usually they are not reported in ICA. The unavailability of S.F. tables has led us to evaluate the correctness of the space group change by comparison of the revised bond lengths and angles with those normally accepted in literature. In particular the word “accepted” means reference to the tables of bond lengths reported in papers .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The Cr atom lies on a twofold axis passing between the two pyridine molecules and the carbonyl groups. The twofold molecular axis noted by the original authors became now a crystallographic axis. Otherwise, the structure is effectively unchanged from that described by the original authors.</ce:para>

The twofold molecular axis noted by the original authors became now a crystallographic axis. Otherwise, the structure is effectively unchanged from that described by the original authors.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.04. Hydrogen atoms were never considered, all atoms were refined anisotropically but N(2) was initially not included. At this point a Fourier map, reported in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, revealed that the electron density in the region of N(2) atom is distributed over a torus about the fourfold axis, but not uniformly as reported by the original authors, but instead with four maxima located on the ±<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> and ±<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> axes. These four maxima were interpreted as due to the N(2) atom disordered about the fourfold axis and statistically distributed over special positions 8(s) of space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4/<ce:italic>mmm</ce:italic>. This may be explained by the low symmetry of the ethylenediammine molecule that try to fit a site with higher symmetry than it can take, the C(2) carbon atom of en is not disordered because the C–C bond of en lies exactly along the fourfold axis. Since the cell contains only one en molecule, i.e. two N(2) atoms, this atom was refined with site occupation factor fixed at (1/4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∗<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(8/16)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.125, namely there is 1/4 of N(2) atom for each of the eight 8(s) special positions.</ce:para>

, revealed that the electron density in the region of N(2) atom is distributed over a torus about the fourfold axis, but not uniformly as reported by the original authors, but instead with four maxima located on the ±x and ±y axes. These four maxima were interpreted as due to the N(2) atom disordered about the fourfold axis and statistically distributed over special positions 8(s) of space group P4/mmm. This may be explained by the low symmetry of the ethylenediammine molecule that try to fit a site with higher symmetry than it can take, the C(2) carbon atom of en is not disordered because the C–C bond of en lies exactly along the fourfold axis. Since the cell contains only one en molecule, i.e. two N(2) atoms, this atom was refined with site occupation factor fixed at (1/4)∗(8/16)=0.125, namely there is 1/4 of N(2) atom for each of the eight 8(s) special positions.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The final usual <ce:italic>R</ce:italic> index was 7.93% for 378 reflections and 32 parameters. This <ce:italic>R</ce:italic> index is better than that obtained by the previous authors, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.90% for 619 reflections but with much more parameters. As expected when the space group change is between two centrosymmetric space group, the distances and angles are very similar to those obtained in the original work, however, in the more symmetric space group the angles Cd–N(1)–C(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>179.22° and Ni–C(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>178.38° become exactly 180.00°, moreover the benzene ring is now contained in the mirror plane at <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 and perpendicular to a, thus perfectly bisecting the Cd–Ni–Cd angle.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The final usual R index was 7.93% for 378 reflections and 32 parameters. This R index is better than that obtained by the previous authors, R
=8.90% for 619 reflections but with much more parameters. As expected when the space group change is between two centrosymmetric space group, the distances and angles are very similar to those obtained in the original work, however, in the more symmetric space group the angles Cd–N(1)–C(1)=179.22° and Ni–C(1)–N(1)=178.38° become exactly 180.00°, moreover the benzene ring is now contained in the mirror plane at x
=1/2 and perpendicular to a, thus perfectly bisecting the Cd–Ni–Cd angle.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We add a comment to the Cd(II) coordination geometry, the Cd(II)–N(2) distance of 2.28(3) Å, is slightly shorter than the usual Cd–NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> distance found in the similar compounds ENCDNA01 (2.35 Å), ENCDNA02 (2.34 Å) and ENCDNB01 (2.32 Å), here however, the en molecule is chelated to the same Cd atom. This shortening is surely due to the disordered of the en molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We add a comment to the Cd(II) coordination geometry, the Cd(II)–N(2) distance of 2.28(3) Å, is slightly shorter than the usual Cd–NH2 distance found in the similar compounds ENCDNA01 (2.35 Å), ENCDNA02 (2.34 Å) and ENCDNB01 (2.32 Å), here however, the en molecule is chelated to the same Cd atom. This shortening is surely due to the disordered of the en molecule.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We must note that BEMKEJ10 (space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4/<ce:italic>mmm</ce:italic>) is isomorphous with ENCNBZ, the only difference is that the en molecule is replaced by 2-aminoethanol, also this group is disordered about the fourfold axis, so much that its positions, reported in the original publication, have not been retained in the CSD file.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We must note that BEMKEJ10 (space group P4/mmm) is isomorphous with ENCNBZ, the only difference is that the en molecule is replaced by 2-aminoethanol, also this group is disordered about the fourfold axis, so much that its positions, reported in the original publication, have not been retained in the CSD file.

HEFPAJ: potassium (N,N-dicarboxymethyl-L-phenylalanyl)-L-leucyl-cobalt hydrate
The structure of this chiral molecule was described  in the monoclinic space group P21 (No. 4), Z
=4. The original authors report Z
=2, but this is not in agreement with the density and the absorption coefficient, thus we have considered Z
=4 the correct value. Moreover, also CSD reports Z
=4. The equality of a and c and β
=90.04° suggest higher symmetry. The transformations x′=−z
−0.5000, y′=−x
+0.5000, z′=
y result in coordinates that are in accord with space group P43 (No. 78), Z
=4. Even if the water molecules are described by the original authors as disordered, they present low shifts: O(1)–O(3)=0.01, O(2)–O(4)=0.02 and O(5)–O(6)=0.02 Å. However, the water molecules O(7) has no symmetry related counterpart, thus it was introduced in the HEFPAJ.CIF file with site occupation factor=0.5.

A particular disordered situation has been found for tetrahydrofurane molecule, in fact, this molecule is disordered across the mirror plane, but in a manner that the oxygen atom is mirrored with the carbon atom C(27), i.e., the mirror plane passes through C(28) atom and between C(25) and C(26) atoms. The structure of this compound was described  in the monoclinic space group P21 (No. 4), Z

=89.98°, Z
=4) space group Cmc21 (No. 36). The vectors defining the orthorhombic cell are

Sm(1) and B(3) atom of bis(pyrazolyl)borato ligand are at Wyckoff position 4(a) on the mirror plane, also two pyrazole rings, one for each tris(pyrazolyl)-borato ligands, and the corresponding B(1) and B(2) atoms lie on the same mirror plane, thus the whole molecule presents C
s(m) symmetry. A particular disordered situation has been found for tetrahydrofurane molecule, in fact, this molecule is disordered across the mirror plane, but in a manner that the oxygen atom is mirrored with the carbon atom C(27), i.e., the mirror plane passes through C(28) atom and between C(25) and C(26) atoms. The bond parameters remain unchanged, the two equivalent distances N(7)–C(10)=1.284 and N(11)–C(16)=1.278 Å become 1.280 Å in Cmc 21 but are shorter than the accepted N–C distance (1.339 Å) in pyrazolylborates coordinated to a metal ion.

The original authors also remark that this compound possesses a probable space group Cmcm, but refinement in Cmcm was not successful (poor convergence, higher e.s.d.’s, higher R values than in P21/m). The failure to achieve satisfactory refinement was probably due to an erroneous assignment of site multiplicities of the disordered DMF molecule. 2v

2v

KAMWUQ: N-hexyl-N-methyl-2-azonia-[3]-ferrocenophane iodide
This compound was described  as monoclinic, space group P21/c (No. 14), with a
=15.115, b
=11.873, c
=21.425 Å, β
=90.21°, Z
=8, namely with two crystallographically independent molecules. However, the coordinate transformations x′=
x, y′=−y, z′=−z lead to the orthorhombic space group Pbca (No. 61), Z
=8. The revised β′ angle (89.79°) appears to differ from the expected value of 90° by several e.s.d.’s, but convincing proof of the orthorhombic symmetry comes from comparison of the atomic coordinates of the two purportedly independent molecules. In fact, they are related by a glide plane a in space group Pbca. The molecular geometry is practically unchanged. However, we note that the C(sp3)–C(sp3) bond lengths along the aliphatic chain remain shorter (mean 1.44 Å) than expected, in particular the original equivalent distances C(17)–C(18)=1.36(3) and C(36)–C(37)=1.27(4) Å are unrealistic and are only slightly changed becoming C(17)–C(18)=1.31 Å.

KUGGEY: pentakis(tetramethylammonium) tetrakis(μ
4-sulfido)-nonachloro-hexa-copper-molybdenum
This compound was reported  in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 (No. 36), with a
=19.945, b
=11.513, c
=20.541, Z
=4. The original authors remark: ‘After standing several days at room temperature black hexagonal crystals deposited’ and also ‘The six copper atoms form a distorted octahedron, the local idealized symmetry is lowered to C
3v
’. In fact, the Niggli matrix corresponds to lattice character No. 12 (hP). The primitive cell, defined by lattice vectors 

[
0



1


¯



0
]

, [0.50.50.0], [001], have dimensions a′=11.513, b′=11.515, c′=20.541 Å, α′=90.00°, β′=90.00°, γ′=120.00°, Z
=2. The revised space group is P63
cm (No. 185). The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−y, y′=2x, z′=
z. Mo(1) and S(1) atoms lie on the 63 axis, Wyckoff position 2(a), site symmetry C
3v
 (3m). Cu(1), Cl(1) and Cl(5) atoms lie on the mirror plane bisecting a and b axes, while Cu(3), S(2), and Cl(3) atoms lie on the mirror plane coincident with the (b,c) face. The description of the [MoS4(CuCl)6Cl3]5− anion made by the original authors is still valid because the shifts for conforming to the higher symmetry are low (maximum shift=0.014 Å for Cl(1)–Cl(2) pair), but the true molecular symmetry is exactly C
3v
, rather than idealized C
3v
, as reported by the original authors. Also the two [N(CH3)4]+ cations conform to the more symmetric space group, one cation lies on the mirror plane, Wyckoff position 6(c), while the other lies with one N–C bond coincident with a ternary axis, Wyckoff position 4(b). Also in this case the shifts are low, maximum shift is 0.052 Å for the C(2)–C(2) pair.

LIVZUL: (1,3-diaminopropane-N-((2-aminophenyl) methylene)-N′-(salicylideneiminato))-copper(II)
This compound was described  as monoclinic, space group P21/n (No. 14), with a
=7.804, b
=7.918, c
=24.445 Å, β
=89.99°, Z
=4. Moreover, in the same paper the chemically similar Ni(II) derivative (LIVZOF) was described as orthorhombic, space group Pnma (No. 62), Z
=4. However, the β angle very near to 90° and the similar compound LIVZOF, strongly suggest an orthorhombic cell. In fact, the coordinate transformations x′=
y, y′=
−z, z′=
x show that the two compounds are isomorphous, with the molecule lying on the mirror plane. The atomic shifts are very small thus there is no variation in molecular geometry. In the original structure the amide NH and the phenoxide O positions are disordered, now the presence of the crystallographic mirror plane imposes, all the more reason, equality between the amide NH and the phenoxide O positions, thus in the CIF file this position is indicate with X1. The change of space group provides the natural explanation for the sentence reported by the original authors ‘the (two) compounds are very similar with both metals in a square planar environment provided by the N
3
O donor ligand’.

<ce:section-title>METHEY: dichloro-(1,3-bis(dimethylamino)propane-N,N′)-nickel(II)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of this neutral Ni(II) complex was solved  in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (No. 4), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, however, the correct value is <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 as suggested by the absorption coefficient reported by the original authors 2.11 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 it should be 1.05 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Moreover, the density calculated with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 is too low (0.751 g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>), also the CSD file reports <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 and density<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.501 g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>. The equality of <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> cell parameters suggests higher symmetry, in fact, the monoclinic cell can be transformed to orthorhombic [<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.403, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.972, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>22.291 Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90.00°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90.00°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>89.86°, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8], space group <ce:italic>Cmc</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (No. 36). The origin must be shifted by Δ<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.2500, Δ<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2500 and the vectors defining the orthorhombic cell are [1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1], <mml:math altimg="si66.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:math>. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2500, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−1/2<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2500, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>. The molecule lies on the crystallographic mirror plane of <ce:italic>Cmc</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, in particular the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-plane passes through Ni, the two chlorine atoms and the central carbon atom of the propane chain of the diamine ligand. This space group change shows that METHEY possess the same space group and similar cell dimensions of other three metal complexes (METGEX, METGIB, METHAU) reported in Table 5 of the original paper. Moreover, a comparison of the atomic coordinates of these four complexes shows that they are, indeed, isomorphous and not only isostructural as reported by the original authors and by the CSD file.</ce:para>

METHEY: dichloro-(1,3-bis(dimethylamino)propane-N,N′)-nickel(II)
The structure of this neutral Ni(II) complex was solved  in the monoclinic space group P21 (No. 4), Z
=2, however, the correct value is Z
=4 as suggested by the absorption coefficient reported by the original authors 2.11 mm−1, with Z
=2 it should be 1.05 mm−1. Moreover, the density calculated with Z
=2 is too low (0.751 gcm−3), also the CSD file reports Z
=4 and density=1.501 gcm−3. The equality of a and c cell parameters suggests higher symmetry, in fact, the monoclinic cell can be transformed to orthorhombic [a′=9.403, b′=10.972, c′=22.291 Å, α′=90.00°, β′=90.00°, γ′=89.86°, Z
=8], space group Cmc21 (No. 36). The origin must be shifted by Δx
=−0.2500, Δy
=0.2500 and the vectors defining the orthorhombic cell are [101], 

[


1


¯



0

1
]

, 

[
0



1


¯



0
]

. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=1/2x
+1/2z
+0.2500, y′=−1/2x
+1/2z
−0.2500, z′=−y. The molecule lies on the crystallographic mirror plane of Cmc21, in particular the m-plane passes through Ni, the two chlorine atoms and the central carbon atom of the propane chain of the diamine ligand. This space group change shows that METHEY possess the same space group and similar cell dimensions of other three metal complexes (METGEX, METGIB, METHAU) reported in Table 5 of the original paper. Moreover, a comparison of the atomic coordinates of these four complexes shows that they are, indeed, isomorphous and not only isostructural as reported by the original authors and by the CSD file.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>27.865, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>115.76°, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, V<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8608.35 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>. However, CSD file reports <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>27.965 Å, we have used the CSD value because there is a better agreement with the bond lengths reported in the original work. The lattice vectors [1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1], [1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] and [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] transform the monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> cell to rhombohedral with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>21.357, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>21.357, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>21.340 Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>44.39, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>44.39, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>44.21°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4320 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>. However, is better to describe this compound in the hexagonal setting, in fact, the vectors [−1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0], <mml:math altimg="si68.gif" overflow="scroll">

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>959 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>. The Niggli matrix has the form [AAC/−A/2 0 −A/2] and very surprisingly it <ce:italic>surely does not appear</ce:italic> in the International Tables of Crystallography. However, similar transformations were reported for the compound DOKLOE <mml:math altimg="si70.gif" overflow="scroll">

</mml:math>
 and for the compound ZEVQEW <mml:math altimg="si71.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo>
<mml:mi>C</mml:mi>
<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>

</mml:math>
. Since the origin must be shifted to (0.5000, 0.0000, 0.0000), the corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−2<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(2/3)<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(1/3)<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(1/3)<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. Since the direction of <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis is unchanged by the transformation, the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (and also <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>) glide plane is common to both space groups, the systematic absences are unchanged. The [C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> trianion possesses now a perfect <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(32) symmetry. The Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion lies on a twofold axis, Wyckoff position 18(e), since this axis is perpendicular to a threefold axis a perfect equilateral triangle of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions is generated. Upper and down of this triangle there are two half water molecules related by a twofold axis and lying on the threefold axis. Since the distance between the two half water molecules is unrealistic (1.964 Å), it is correct to think (as is reported in the CSD file) that “<ce:italic>the central aqua ligand is equally disordered over two sites</ce:italic>”, we add “related by a twofold axis”. The structure contains solvent accessible voids of 295.00 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.</ce:para>

Upper and down of this triangle there are two half water molecules related by a twofold axis and lying on the threefold axis. Since the distance between the two half water molecules is unrealistic (1.964 Å), it is correct to think (as is reported in the CSD file) that “the central aqua ligand is equally disordered over two sites”, we add “related by a twofold axis”. The structure contains solvent accessible voids of 295.00 Å3.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Also the Niggli matrix suggests this space group change, it is of the form (A<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>A<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>C/D<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>E<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>F), with the supplementary condition 2[D<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>E<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>F]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>A+B, corresponding to lattice character No. 17 (<ce:italic>mC</ce:italic>). The difference between the triclinic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axes, 0.034 Å, is significantly larger than the reported e.s.d.’s (ca. 0.002 Å) and also <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>′ and <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>′ are significantly different from 90°, convincing evidence of the monoclinic symmetry comes from the revised atomic coordinates and from the small atomic shifts. We must note that 75% of the molecules contain two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> OCN groups bonded to Ni(II) while the other 25% contain two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> perchlorate groups bonded to Ni(II). Moreover, the perchlorate anions are disordered as indicate by a short anomalous contact between two perchlorate groups belonging one to molecule A and the other to molecule B, namely O(2)–O(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.21(2) Å. Obviously this anomalous short contact present in the original structure remains also in the revised structure. The new bond parameters are the mean of those described by the original authors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Also the Niggli matrix suggests this space group change, it is of the form (AAC/DEF), with the supplementary condition 2[D+E+F]=A+B, corresponding to lattice character No. 17 (mC). The difference between the triclinic a and b axes, 0.034 Å, is significantly larger than the reported e.s.d.’s (ca. 0.002 Å) and also α′ and γ′ are significantly different from 90°, convincing evidence of the monoclinic symmetry comes from the revised atomic coordinates and from the small atomic shifts. We must note that 75% of the molecules contain two trans OCN groups bonded to Ni(II) while the other 25% contain two trans perchlorate groups bonded to Ni(II). Moreover, the perchlorate anions are disordered as indicate by a short anomalous contact between two perchlorate groups belonging one to molecule A and the other to molecule B, namely O(2)–O(6)=2.21(2) Å. Obviously this anomalous short contact present in the original structure remains also in the revised structure. The new bond parameters are the mean of those described by the original authors.

elements.clean_text:
PAKHIS: tetrakis(μ
2-1,3-di-p-tolyltriazene)-acetonitrile-di-ruthenium tetrafluoroborate
The structure of this compound was reported  in space group P2/n (No. 13), Z
=2, and is here revised to space group P4/n (No. 85), Z
=2. The coordinate transformations are: x′=
z, y′=
x, z′=
y. The atomic shifts for the dimetallic cation are very low ranging from 0.01 for the N(1)–N(4) pair to 0.05 Å for the C(5)–C(19) pair, mean shift 0.023 Å, but for the disordered [BF4]− anion they are higher. The two Ru atoms as well as the axial acetonitrile molecule reside now on the crystallographic fourfold axis as found for the parent compound Ru2(p-tolNNNp-tol)4(CH3CN) (PAKHAK) described in the same paper, however, the two compounds are not isomorphous even if they have the same space group and similar molecular structure. The Ru–Ru bond length (2.3732(7) Å) does not change (for symmetry considerations).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The [BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion is disordered because it desperately try to respect the fourfold axis, in fact, one B–F bond is ordered and lies along the fourfold axis, but the other three B–F bonds are disordered across the fourfold axis in such a manner that F(3) and F(4) or F(3) and F(2) are nearly related by this axis, in fact, the F(2)–F(4) distance is very short (0.89 Å). This space group change requires that the <ce:italic>β</ce:italic> angle differ from 90° only by a few s.u. and also that the cell parameters a and c differ, in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, only by a few s.u. The deviation of <ce:italic>β</ce:italic> from 90° (0.16°) is in the usual range found in other compounds , while <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.280(2) Å and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.095(4) Å apparently differ by 46 <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.185 Å), this is a very high value. Herbstein reports  that four-circle diffractometer measurements may give precision of some parts in 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> under optimal conditions. However, Taylor and Kennard report  that the s.u.’s of cell lengths are grossly underestimated by an average factor of about 5. This means that in reality we have <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.02–0.03 Å, than Δ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.185 Å correspond to 6–9 <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>, still an high value. However, the crystal and molecular structure possess a fourfold axis within the standard uncertainties and we have not found any crystallographic reason for which <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axes should be different, moreover the original authors make no comment concerning the possibility of higher symmetry, thus we have deposited the PAKHIS.CIF file with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>4/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (No. 85).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The [BF4]− anion is disordered because it desperately try to respect the fourfold axis, in fact, one B–F bond is ordered and lies along the fourfold axis, but the other three B–F bonds are disordered across the fourfold axis in such a manner that F(3) and F(4) or F(3) and F(2) are nearly related by this axis, in fact, the F(2)–F(4) distance is very short (0.89 Å). This space group change requires that the β angle differ from 90° only by a few s.u. and also that the cell parameters a and c differ, in space group P2/n, only by a few s.u. The deviation of β from 90° (0.16°) is in the usual range found in other compounds , while a
=13.280(2) Å and c
=13.095(4) Å apparently differ by 46 σ (Δ
=0.185 Å), this is a very high value. Herbstein reports  that four-circle diffractometer measurements may give precision of some parts in 104 under optimal conditions. However, Taylor and Kennard report  that the s.u.’s of cell lengths are grossly underestimated by an average factor of about 5. This means that in reality we have σ
=0.02–0.03 Å, than Δ=0.185 Å correspond to 6–9 σ, still an high value. However, the crystal and molecular structure possess a fourfold axis within the standard uncertainties and we have not found any crystallographic reason for which a and c axes should be different, moreover the original authors make no comment concerning the possibility of higher symmetry, thus we have deposited the PAKHIS.CIF file with space group P4/n (No. 85).

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>SEVLIO). Matikainen et al. noted that ‘<ce:italic>The structure consists of monomeric molecules adopting crystallographic m symmetry. Thus all atoms except O(2) occupy the mirror plane at y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>=</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>1/4.</ce:italic>’. Seven years later Martin-Zarza et al. , using a different synthetic method, obtained an apparently triclinic form of the same compound (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>SEVLIO01), in fact, they remark ‘<ce:italic>We recrystallized 1</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>i.e.,</ce:italic> this compound) <ce:italic>in the presence of CrO</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>while in the work of Matikainen et al. it was done in a CrO</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>-free medium. These conditions led to a new crystal phase for compound 1</ce:italic>’ (i.e., a new polymorph).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
SEVLIO01:(pyridinium-3-carboxylato)-trioxo-chromium or trioxo-(nicotinato-O)-chromium(VI)
In 1990 Matikainen et al.  reported the structure of this compound as monoclinic, space group P21/m (No. 11), Z
=2, (Refcode=SEVLIO). Matikainen et al. noted that ‘The structure consists of monomeric molecules adopting crystallographic m symmetry. Thus all atoms except O(2) occupy the mirror plane at y

=

1/4.’. Seven years later Martin-Zarza et al. , using a different synthetic method, obtained an apparently triclinic form of the same compound (Refcode=SEVLIO01), in fact, they remark ‘We recrystallized 1 (i.e., this compound) in the presence of CrO
3, while in the work of Matikainen et al. it was done in a CrO
3
-free medium. These conditions led to a new crystal phase for compound 1’ (i.e., a new polymorph).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We note that the original authors say: ‘<ce:italic>The symmetry is C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">S</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>all atoms lying in the same plane with the exception of two terminal oxygens.</ce:italic>’ In fact, this space group change imposes that the pyridinium-3-carboxylato moiety, Cr and one oxygen atom of the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> group lie on the mirror plane at <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/4 (maximum deviation<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.024 Å for C(1)), while O(2) and O(3) atoms are related by this mirror plane with shift<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.01 Å. The two distances Cr–O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.603(6) and Cr–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.588(6) became 1.596(6) Å, in SEVLIO this distance is 1.5971(5) Å. Otherwise, the structure is effectively unchanged from that described by Martin-Zarza et al. .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
We note that the original authors say: ‘The symmetry is C
S, all atoms lying in the same plane with the exception of two terminal oxygens.’ In fact, this space group change imposes that the pyridinium-3-carboxylato moiety, Cr and one oxygen atom of the CrO3 group lie on the mirror plane at y
=1/4 (maximum deviation=0.024 Å for C(1)), while O(2) and O(3) atoms are related by this mirror plane with shift=0.01 Å. The two distances Cr–O(2)=1.603(6) and Cr–O(3)=1.588(6) became 1.596(6) Å, in SEVLIO this distance is 1.5971(5) Å. Otherwise, the structure is effectively unchanged from that described by Martin-Zarza et al. .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The situation for the <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-aminosalicylato group is more complicated, in fact the phenyl ring and the carboxylic group must lie perpendicular to the mirror plane with the C–NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group contained on it, thus the phenolic oxygen is constrained to lie on two sites related by this mirror plane, for this reason this oxygen atom is also here reported with site occupation factor equal to 0.5. The new space group thus explain the disorder of the phenolic oxygen found by the original authors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The situation for the p-aminosalicylato group is more complicated, in fact the phenyl ring and the carboxylic group must lie perpendicular to the mirror plane with the C–NH2 group contained on it, thus the phenolic oxygen is constrained to lie on two sites related by this mirror plane, for this reason this oxygen atom is also here reported with site occupation factor equal to 0.5. The new space group thus explain the disorder of the phenolic oxygen found by the original authors.

VISCUV: (−)-mer-bis(ethylenediamine-N-acetato-O,O′,N,N′,N″,N‴)-cobalt(III) bromide
This chiral complex was described  as orthorhombic, space group P212121 (No. 19), Z
=4. The equality of a and c might have given rise to suspicions about higher symmetry. The transformations x′=
z
+0.2500, y′=
x, z′=
y
+0.3750 lead to coordinates that are consistent with the symmetry of the tetragonal space group P41212 (No. 92), Z
=4. The atomic shifts to achieve the higher symmetry are very low. The molecule, which has C
1 symmetry in the original orthorhombic description is located about a twofold axis in the revised description, this axis passes through the Co(III) ion and between N(1)–N(3), N(2)–N(4) and O(1)–O(3) pairs, also the Br− ion reside on the twofold axis. No variation in bond parameters or in the absolute configuration was noted, in fact, we have only add a twofold axis to the molecule.

elements.clean_text:
Category B – add a centre of symmetry
BARKEK: (η
5-cyclopentadienyl)-nitrito-dinitrosyl-chromium
This structure was reported  in the non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21 (No. 33), Z
=4 (in the original publication is reported Z
=8, but with this value the calculated density become too high, 3.51 gcm−3, moreover also CSD reports Z
=4). The coordinate transformations x′=−x, y′=
z, z′=
y show that this structure can be described in the centrosymmetric space group Pnma (No. 62). The molecules are in Wyckoff positions 4(c) (symmetry m), the mirror plane passes through Cr(1), N(3), O(3), O(4) atoms and probably C(3), that is one atom of the Cp ring.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">However, the Cp ring show considerable libration motion around the Cr–Cp axis, as is indicated by the shortening of the mean C–C distance (1.34 Å) and by the anisotropic thermal factors (Bij) (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar Cp ring disorder is also present in the analogous compound [η<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>-(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)Cr(NO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl] (CPNCRC01) . The refinement in the incorrect non-centrosymmetric space group and the libration motion have considerably deformed the Cp ring (the five C–C distances range from 1.22 to 1.49 Å) making difficult to understand what atom must reside on the mirror plane. However, considering that near-singularities must produce short and long mirrored distances, we have identified as C(3) the atom that must reside on the mirror plane. The five distances of the Cp ring now become 1.37, 1.35, 1.35, 1.32, 1.32 Å, but they are still much shorter than the accepted C–C distance (1.42 Å). Even if this shortening is explicable on the basis of the libration motion, we have prepared the CIF file imposing a regular C–C distance of 1.42 Å. Since other rotamers of the Cp ring are equally plausible (for example, C(1) on the mirror plane), further refinement is clearly needed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
However, the Cp ring show considerable libration motion around the Cr–Cp axis, as is indicated by the shortening of the mean C–C distance (1.34 Å) and by the anisotropic thermal factors (Bij) (see 
). Similar Cp ring disorder is also present in the analogous compound [η5-(C5H5)Cr(NO)2Cl] (CPNCRC01) . The refinement in the incorrect non-centrosymmetric space group and the libration motion have considerably deformed the Cp ring (the five C–C distances range from 1.22 to 1.49 Å) making difficult to understand what atom must reside on the mirror plane. However, considering that near-singularities must produce short and long mirrored distances, we have identified as C(3) the atom that must reside on the mirror plane. The five distances of the Cp ring now become 1.37, 1.35, 1.35, 1.32, 1.32 Å, but they are still much shorter than the accepted C–C distance (1.42 Å). Even if this shortening is explicable on the basis of the libration motion, we have prepared the CIF file imposing a regular C–C distance of 1.42 Å. Since other rotamers of the Cp ring are equally plausible (for example, C(1) on the mirror plane), further refinement is clearly needed.

<ce:section-title>BIPNAP: bis(bis(2-pyridyl)amine)-copper(II) bis(tetrafluoroborate)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of this compound was described  in space group <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> (No. 9), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, but it is better described in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 15), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. In fact, the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> coordinates can be obtained using the transformations: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3957, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3896. The copper(II) ion now lies on the crystallographic twofold axis along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> and therefore the exact point group symmetry of the cation is <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, in this manner the two bis(2-pyridyl)amine molecules, bonded to Cu(II), are related by this twofold axis. The space group change shows that this compound is isomorphous with the diperchlorate analogous compound, namely the compound that contains the perchlorate ion in place of [BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion. The crystal and molecular structure of the diperchlorate derivative has been reported in literature three times (see Refcodes: DPYACU10, DPYACU01, DPYACU11), the first study, as noted by the original authors, comes back to 1971. The Cu(II)–N distances become more regular, now they are 1.964 and 1.960 Å, while in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> they range from 1.945(5) to 1.975(5) Å, also the distances in the bis(2-pyridyl)amine become more regular, for example the C–N distances about the bridging nitrogen are now 1.370 and 1.375 Å, while in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> they are 1.328, 1.389, 1.362 and 1.412 Å. We must note that the distortion about the bridging nitrogen was found also in DPYACU10 (made in 1971) but the more accurate structures DPYACU01 and DPYACU11 do not show this distortion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
BIPNAP: bis(bis(2-pyridyl)amine)-copper(II) bis(tetrafluoroborate)
The structure of this compound was described  in space group Cc (No. 9), Z
=4, but it is better described in C2/c (No. 15), Z
=4. In fact, the C2/c coordinates can be obtained using the transformations: x′=−x
+0.3957, y′=
y, z′=−z
+0.3896. The copper(II) ion now lies on the crystallographic twofold axis along b and therefore the exact point group symmetry of the cation is C
2, in this manner the two bis(2-pyridyl)amine molecules, bonded to Cu(II), are related by this twofold axis. The space group change shows that this compound is isomorphous with the diperchlorate analogous compound, namely the compound that contains the perchlorate ion in place of [BF4]− ion. The crystal and molecular structure of the diperchlorate derivative has been reported in literature three times (see Refcodes: DPYACU10, DPYACU01, DPYACU11), the first study, as noted by the original authors, comes back to 1971. The Cu(II)–N distances become more regular, now they are 1.964 and 1.960 Å, while in Cc they range from 1.945(5) to 1.975(5) Å, also the distances in the bis(2-pyridyl)amine become more regular, for example the C–N distances about the bridging nitrogen are now 1.370 and 1.375 Å, while in Cc they are 1.328, 1.389, 1.362 and 1.412 Å. We must note that the distortion about the bridging nitrogen was found also in DPYACU10 (made in 1971) but the more accurate structures DPYACU01 and DPYACU11 do not show this distortion.

DIYGUN: bis(bis(μ
2-oxo))-bis(2,6-di-isopropyl phenoxy)-bis(tetrahydrofuran)-lithium-vanadium
This compound was described  in space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=1. The original authors reported: ‘the intensities of the standard reflections decreased by 34.5%’, and also ‘the relatively low precision of the structure…is due to the low quality of the crystal’. In fact, the range of C–C distances in the four benzene rings is noteworthy, from 1.25 to 1.49 Å, also the range of the four V–O distances in cis-dioxovanadium(V) groups

P


1


¯

1


¯



 model is derived by shifting the origin between the two vanadium atoms and symmetrizing pairs of related atoms. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=

−0.03276, y′=

−0.30795, z′=

−0.35611. All tests used show that the space group change is needed, but the R

=10.40% is relatively high, this is due to the relatively low precision of the original structure, especially in the region of one isopropyl group and one tetrahydrofuran molecule. However, the 

P


1


¯



 model leads to a noticeable improvement in bond parameters, for example the C–C distances in benzene rings now range from 1.36 to 1.40 Å and the

<ce:section-title>GOBHEK: bis-(1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato)-(1,2-ethanediamine)-cobalt(II)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This compound was reported  in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> (No. 9), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. However, it should be described as monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 15), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. For describing the structure in the conventional setting of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> there is no need of reorienting the cell axes but only of shifting the origin by Δ<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2923, Δ<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1488. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2923; <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>; <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1488. In the revised structure the twofold axis along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> passes through Co(II), the midpoint of the 1,2-ethanediamine C–C bond and between the two 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato ligands. There is a large spread of C–C distances in the four phenyl rings, from 1.30 to 1.44 Å. In the revised structure the phenyl bonds range from 1.35 to 1.40 Å. Also the other distances are improved, for example the four Co(II)–O bonds ranging in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> from 1.996(10) to 2.110(10) Å are in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> reduced to two Co(II)–O distances with values 2.05 and 2.06 Å. We have found only two other compounds, ECANIF and ECANUR, having the 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato ligand bonded to a Co(II) ion, they have a mean Co(II)–O distance of 2.03 and 2.05 Å, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
GOBHEK: bis-(1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato)-(1,2-ethanediamine)-cobalt(II)
This compound was reported  in the monoclinic space group Cc (No. 9), Z
=4. However, it should be described as monoclinic space group C2/c (No. 15), Z
=4. For describing the structure in the conventional setting of C2/c there is no need of reorienting the cell axes but only of shifting the origin by Δx
=0.2923, Δz
=0.1488. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−0.2923; y′=
y; z′=
z
−0.1488. In the revised structure the twofold axis along b passes through Co(II), the midpoint of the 1,2-ethanediamine C–C bond and between the two 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato ligands. There is a large spread of C–C distances in the four phenyl rings, from 1.30 to 1.44 Å. In the revised structure the phenyl bonds range from 1.35 to 1.40 Å. Also the other distances are improved, for example the four Co(II)–O bonds ranging in Cc from 1.996(10) to 2.110(10) Å are in C2/c reduced to two Co(II)–O distances with values 2.05 and 2.06 Å. We have found only two other compounds, ECANIF and ECANUR, having the 1,3-diphenyl-1,3-propanedionato ligand bonded to a Co(II) ion, they have a mean Co(II)–O distance of 2.03 and 2.05 Å, respectively.

KARQUP: trans-dichloro-bis(3-picoline)-platinum
This compound was reported  as triclinic, space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=1. However, shifting the origin on the platinum atom a centrosymmetric structure, space group 

P


1


¯



 (No. 2), can be obtained. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x

y

z
−0.2000. The Pt–Cl and Pt–N distances are in 

P


1


¯



 2.298 and 2.017 Å, respectively, they are little affected by the space group change, thus the discussion about these distances reported in the original paper is still valid. Moreover, comparison of bond lengths related by the centre of symmetry shows appreciable discrepancies for 3-picoline ligands, the four C–N bonds range from 1.32 to 1.37 Å in P1, while in

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. In fact, the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> coordinates can be obtained by the relationships: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2430, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3370. The Cu(II) ion lies on the crystallographic twofold axis along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>, thus the whole complex has exact <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> symmetry. As in other examples, the spread in bond lengths is an artefact due to the near singularities introduced by the wrong space group, for example, in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> the four C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C double bonds in the two thiophene rings are 1.16–1.53 and 1.37–1.38 Å, but are at 1.34 and 1.38 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, (accepted C(2)–C(3), C(4)–C(5) distances in thiophene<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.362 Å). elements.clean_text:
LAGQEP: cis-bis(nitrato-O,O′)-bis(1-(2-pyridyl)-2-(2-thienyl)ethyne-N)-copper
This compound was reported  in space group Cc (No. 9), Z
=4, but it is better described in space group C2/c (No. 15), Z
=4. In fact, the C2/c coordinates can be obtained by the relationships: x′=−x
+0.2430, y′=
y, z′=−z
+0.3370. The Cu(II) ion lies on the crystallographic twofold axis along b, thus the whole complex has exact C
2 symmetry. As in other examples, the spread in bond lengths is an artefact due to the near singularities introduced by the wrong space group, for example, in Cc the four CC double bonds in the two thiophene rings are 1.16–1.53 and 1.37–1.38 Å, but are at 1.34 and 1.38 Å in C2/c, (accepted C(2)–C(3), C(4)–C(5) distances in thiophene=1.362 Å). Similarly, the C–C distances in the two pyridine rings ranged from 1.31 to 1.49 Å, now they range from 1.38 to 1.40 Å, (accepted C–C distances in pyridine 1.379 Å).

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) is too low, the correct density, calculated by us with <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, is 1.752 g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, a more realistic value for such a dinuclear compound.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
METBIW: bis((μ
2-carbonato-O,O,O′)-(bis(2-pyridyl)amine)-copper(II)) monohydrate
This dinuclear compound was reported  as monoclinic, space group Cc (No. 9), Z
=2. However, Z
=4 is the correct value, in fact, the density 0.902 gcm−3 (calculated by the original authors with Z
=2) is too low, the correct density, calculated by us with Z
=4, is 1.752 gcm−3, a more realistic value for such a dinuclear compound.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">This structure is better described in space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 15) and the corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2145, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3702; the translations are needed to place the centre of symmetry at (1/4, 1/4, 0) between the two copper ions, in this manner this dinuclear complex becomes centrosymmetric, in fact, not only the two copper ions but also the two carbonato and the two bis(2-pyridyl)amine groups are related by this centre of symmetry. The water molecule lies on the twofold axis along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>, in fact, only four water molecules are contained in the cell. The atomic shifts are low considering that the change is from a non-centrosymmetric to a centro-symmetric space group. We now show that a comparison between similar compounds is, inter alia, very useful to ascertain the absence of the centre of symmetry. Thus we have recovered from the CSD file two similar compounds (COJGAJ-COJGAJ01 and TAGMAP) containing only one bis(pyridyl)amine molecule and one carbonato group coordinated to a copper(II) ion in a bidentate fashion. We have seen that the maximum shift is for the C(19)–C(20) pair, a carbon atom of bis(2-pyridyl)amine molecule. In fact, this molecule is deformed by the refinement in the non-centrosymmetric space group, for example the two chemically equivalent (in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic>) distances C(17)–C(20)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.277(2) and C(18)–C(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.450(9) Å become in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> 1.368 Å, that is comparable to the mean value of 1.362 Å found in the two analogous complexes. Similarly, the chemically equivalent distances (in <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic>) C(1)–C(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.460(9) and C(4)–C(18)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.354(10) Å become in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> 1.405 Å against 1.400 Å as the mean of the two compounds. In <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic> one carbonato group is strongly asymmetric with C(5)–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.274(8) and C(5)–O(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.319(8) Å, while the other is perfectly symmetric with C(7)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.342(8) and C(7)–O(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.341(8) Å. In the new description these distances become C(5)–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.307 and C(5)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.330 Å. Probably this little difference is real, since O(4) is bonded to two copper(II) ions while O(3) is bonded to only one copper(II) ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
This structure is better described in space group C2/c (No. 15) and the corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=−x
−0.2145, y′=
y
+1/2, z′=−z
+0.3702; the translations are needed to place the centre of symmetry at (1/4, 1/4, 0) between the two copper ions, in this manner this dinuclear complex becomes centrosymmetric, in fact, not only the two copper ions but also the two carbonato and the two bis(2-pyridyl)amine groups are related by this centre of symmetry. The water molecule lies on the twofold axis along b, in fact, only four water molecules are contained in the cell. The atomic shifts are low considering that the change is from a non-centrosymmetric to a centro-symmetric space group. We now show that a comparison between similar compounds is, inter alia, very useful to ascertain the absence of the centre of symmetry. Thus we have recovered from the CSD file two similar compounds (COJGAJ-COJGAJ01 and TAGMAP) containing only one bis(pyridyl)amine molecule and one carbonato group coordinated to a copper(II) ion in a bidentate fashion. We have seen that the maximum shift is for the C(19)–C(20) pair, a carbon atom of bis(2-pyridyl)amine molecule. In fact, this molecule is deformed by the refinement in the non-centrosymmetric space group, for example the two chemically equivalent (in Cc) distances C(17)–C(20)=1.277(2) and C(18)–C(19)=1.450(9) Å become in C2/c 1.368 Å, that is comparable to the mean value of 1.362 Å found in the two analogous complexes. Similarly, the chemically equivalent distances (in Cc) C(1)–C(7)=1.460(9) and C(4)–C(18)=1.354(10) Å become in C2/c 1.405 Å against 1.400 Å as the mean of the two compounds. In Cc one carbonato group is strongly asymmetric with C(5)–O(3)=1.274(8) and C(5)–O(6)=1.319(8) Å, while the other is perfectly symmetric with C(7)–O(4)=1.342(8) and C(7)–O(5)=1.341(8) Å. In the new description these distances become C(5)–O(3)=1.307 and C(5)–O(4)=1.330 Å. Probably this little difference is real, since O(4) is bonded to two copper(II) ions while O(3) is bonded to only one copper(II) ion.

<ce:section-title>NIGGIT: tris(trimethylphosphine)-p-tolylthiolato-(triphenylsilyl)-hydrido-rhodium(III) benzene solvate</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This structure was reported  in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (No. 4), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>

<ce:italic>(No. 4)) was chosen since the calculation based on the other</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>i.e., P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>) <ce:italic>do not give any reasonable structures</ce:italic>’. NIGGIT: tris(trimethylphosphine)-p-tolylthiolato-(triphenylsilyl)-hydrido-rhodium(III) benzene solvate
This structure was reported  in space group P21 (No. 4), Z
=2, but is better described in space group P21/m (No. 11). The original authors note ‘The proper space group (P21
(No. 4)) was chosen since the calculation based on the other (i.e., P21/m) do not give any reasonable structures’. However, the coordinates reported are entirely compatible with P21/m, in fact, the coordinate transformations are: x′=
z, y′=−y, z′=
x. The mirror plane passes through Rh, H(1), S, P(3), C(9), Si, C(29), C(32) atoms, in this manner the entire (S–C6H4–p-CH3) group is coincident with the mirror plane and one phenyl ring (C(29)⋯C(34)) bonded to Si is perpendicular to this mirror plane and it is cut in two equal pieces. Moreover, one solvated benzene molecule is mirrored with another solvated benzene molecule, while the third solvated benzene molecule lies on a centre of symmetry. The spread in bond lengths (e.g., for the benzene rings 1.06(5)–1.66(5), for the P–CH3 bonds 1.68(2)–1.95(2) Å, etc.) is an artefact due to the omission of the centre of symmetry, now in P21/m the molecular geometry is close to standard, in fact, the range of the C–C bond in benzene rings is 1.35–1.40 and of P–CH3 bonds is 1.82–1.84 Å.

This structure was described  in space group Ia (No. 9), Z
=4, but it is better described in I2/a (No. 15), Z
=4. In fact, after the origin is shifted by Δx
=0.2109, Δz

2 axis passes through Ir, C(1), O(1) (C(1)–O(1)=carbonyl) and between P(1) and P(2) atoms, however, the molecular symmetry is approximately C
2v
. The geometry of the complex is greatly improved by the space group change, The two Ir–P equivalent distances 2.33(1) and 2.42(1) Å become in I2/a 2.38 Å. The mean Ir–P distance in hexacoordinated Ir complexes containing two tri-isopropylphosphine in trans position is 2.366 Å in KUMPAJ and 2.394 Å in NIGKET. The P–C distances ranged from 1.76 to 1.94 Å in Ia structure, in the revised structure they lie between 1.84 and 1.86 Å (accepted P–C(sp3)=1.855 Å). Similarly, the C(sp3)–C(sp3) distances in the isopropylphosphine ligand ranged from 1.44 to 1.69 Å, now in I2/a five of them lie between 1.53 and 1.57 Å and only one is 1.49 Å.

The structure of this dinuclear pentacoordinate copper(II) complex was certainly refined  in the non-centrosymmetric space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=1, even if the original authors report in the abstract and in Table 1 of the original work that the space group is 

P


1

 (No. 2), Z
=1. We are sure of this for the following six reasons:

(i)
The original authors report in Table 2 all the possible bond lengths and not only the independent distances. Thus the chemically equivalent distances, that in 

P


1


¯



 become also crystallographic equivalent, are slightly different.


(ii)
The original authors have deposited at CCDC the coordinates of all the atoms in the molecule and not only the coordinates of the independent atoms.


(iii)
The pseudo-centre of symmetry present in the deposited coordinates is at x
=0.0571, y
=0.2137, z
=0.2837 and not at (0,0,0) or in other equivalent positions.


(iv)
The bond lengths show the distortions characteristic of a centrosymmetric structure refined in a non-centrosymmetric space group.


(v)
The original authors report in the description of the crystal (and molecular) structure that “The structure of 1 consists of a almost centrosymmetric dinuclear [Cu
2
(OH)

(dpyam)

cation”, and also “the cation is approximately planar (dihedral angle 179.9° between the CuO
2
planes)”, however, the presence of a centre of symmetry imposes an exact dihedral angle of 180°.


(vi)
The CCDC centre has distributed the CSD file with space group P1 (No. 1).

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0947, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1330. Since only three benzene rings are reported in the original <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1 cell, one benzene ring must remain unpaired unless it lies on a centre of symmetry, but this is not the case. An other possibility is that the fourth benzene ring is present but was not reported by the original authors. We think that this is the correct circumstance because we note in the cell a void of 155 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> that is centrosymmetrically related with the centre of gravity of one benzene ring. Since a void of 155 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> can contain a benzene ring we are inclined to fill this void with the missing benzene ring. Moreover, the comparison of the atomic coordinates of this compound with those of the copper(II) (QARQAB) and silver(II) (ABOSOZ) analogues, that contain four benzene rings in the cell, clearly suggest that these three compounds are isomorphous, thus removing any doubt about the presence of the fourth benzene ring. We note that in Ref.  QARQAB and ABOSOZ are reported in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1 (No. 1), but this is not in agreement with that reported in ref.  and , we have checked the space group and, without doubt, the space group of these two compounds is <mml:math altimg="si112.gif" overflow="scroll">

<ce:bold>
<ce:italic>almost</ce:italic>
</ce:bold>
<ce:italic>isomorphous structures</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>only the space groups being different</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>acentric P1 and centric</ce:italic>

We must also note that the CSD file reports two years later (under Refcode QARPUU01) that these three compounds are isomorphous, this was suggested to CCDC by a misleading sentence reported in Ref.  and by the above-mentioned space group discrepancies. Only now we can say that these three compounds (QARPUU or QARPUU01-QARQAB-ABOSOZ) are indeed isomorphous.</ce:para>

QARPUU: C60-fullerene (anti-octaethylporphyrinato)-palladium(II) benzene solvate
The QARPUU compound was described  in space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=2. Later on the same research group described  this compound in space group 

P


1


¯



 (No. 2), but the atomic coordinates were not deposited at CCDC. Thus, this new determination was stored by CCDC with space group P1 (No. 1) (under Refcode QARPUU01), in fact, CCDC cannot store the same compound with two different space groups, unless they are polymorphs, but this is not the case. Since the coordinates in 

P


1


¯



 were never reported, we have changed the space group of this compound from P1 to 

P


1


¯



. The coordinate transformations are x′=
z
−0.4242, y′=−x
+0.0947, z′=−y
+0.1330. Since only three benzene rings are reported in the original P1 cell, one benzene ring must remain unpaired unless it lies on a centre of symmetry, but this is not the case. An other possibility is that the fourth benzene ring is present but was not reported by the original authors. We think that this is the correct circumstance because we note in the cell a void of 155 Å3 that is centrosymmetrically related with the centre of gravity of one benzene ring. Since a void of 155 Å3 can contain a benzene ring we are inclined to fill this void with the missing benzene ring. Moreover, the comparison of the atomic coordinates of this compound with those of the copper(II) (QARQAB) and silver(II) (ABOSOZ) analogues, that contain four benzene rings in the cell, clearly suggest that these three compounds are isomorphous, thus removing any doubt about the presence of the fourth benzene ring. We note that in Ref.  QARQAB and ABOSOZ are reported in space group P1 (No. 1), but this is not in agreement with that reported in ref.  and , we have checked the space group and, without doubt, the space group of these two compounds is 

P


1


¯



 (No. 2). We must also note that the original authors report in : ‘These two new compounds (QARPUU and QARQAB) are

almost

isomorphous structures, only the space groups being different, acentric P1 and centric


P


1


¯




for palladium and copper respectively.’. We must also note that the CSD file reports two years later (under Refcode QARPUU01) that these three compounds are isomorphous, this was suggested to CCDC by a misleading sentence reported in Ref.  and by the above-mentioned space group discrepancies. Only now we can say that these three compounds (QARPUU or QARPUU01-QARQAB-ABOSOZ) are indeed isomorphous.
