Since the original authors have placed the Sn(IV) atom on the cell origin, it is not necessary to translate the molecule but only to average the symmetry-related atoms. We have also reoriented the cell axes for following the usual conventions, thus the corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>. The CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and CCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> molecules present a mean atomic shift (0.16 Å) that is slightly greater than that of the bulky Sn(IV) tetraphenylporphinato, however, these solvated molecules are disordered, in fact, the original authors remark ‘<ce:italic>After further cycles of isotropic least-squares refinement it was clear that the chloroform and carbon tetrachloride molecules were partially disordered among two sites in the lattice</ce:italic>’. However, the improvement in molecular geometry has convinced us that this space group change is appropriate, for example the C–C distances in benzene rings range from 1.19 to 1.60 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1, but are at 1.35–1.45 Å in <mml:math altimg="si121.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>¯</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>. Similarly, the Sn–N distances from 2.05 to 2.11 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1, but at 2.08 and 2.10 in <mml:math altimg="si122.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>¯</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>. The N–C distances in pyrrole rings from 1.28 to 1.45 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1, but at 1.34–1.39 Å in <mml:math altimg="si123.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">

<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>¯</mml:mi>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>. In the other two known structures with a Sn(IV) ion exactly encapsulated in the cavity of a tetraphenylporphirin ring, JOZSIA and TPPCSN, we have: Sn–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.07 and 2.10 Å, C–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.385 and 1.370 Å, respectively. Other distances are similarly improved.</ce:para>

TPHSNS: α,β,γ,δ-tetraphenyl-porphinato-(dihydroxy)-tin(IV) chloroform solvate carbon tetrachloride solvate
The structure of this compound was described  in space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=1. It should be described, instead, in space group 

P


1


¯



 (No. 2) with the Sn(IV) atom lying on a centre of symmetry. Since the original authors have placed the Sn(IV) atom on the cell origin, it is not necessary to translate the molecule but only to average the symmetry-related atoms. We have also reoriented the cell axes for following the usual conventions, thus the corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
z, y′=
x, z′=
y. The CHCl3 and CCl4 molecules present a mean atomic shift (0.16 Å) that is slightly greater than that of the bulky Sn(IV) tetraphenylporphinato, however, these solvated molecules are disordered, in fact, the original authors remark ‘After further cycles of isotropic least-squares refinement it was clear that the chloroform and carbon tetrachloride molecules were partially disordered among two sites in the lattice’. However, the improvement in molecular geometry has convinced us that this space group change is appropriate, for example the C–C distances in benzene rings range from 1.19 to 1.60 Å in P1, but are at 1.35–1.45 Å in 

P


1


¯



. Similarly, the Sn–N distances from 2.05 to 2.11 Å in P1, but at 2.08 and 2.10 in 

P


1


¯



. The N–C distances in pyrrole rings from 1.28 to 1.45 Å in P1, but at 1.34–1.39 Å in 

P


1


¯



. In the other two known structures with a Sn(IV) ion exactly encapsulated in the cavity of a tetraphenylporphirin ring, JOZSIA and TPPCSN, we have: Sn–N=2.07 and 2.10 Å, C–N=1.385 and 1.370 Å, respectively. Other distances are similarly improved.

y

The trimethylammoniopropylthiolato ligand now lies, together with the Hg atom, on the mirror plane perpendicular to the fourfold axis, only the two methyl groups C(4) and C(5) lie outside this mirror plane and are related by it. The planar conformation of the ammoniopropylthiolato moiety is distinctive of this compound, in fact, only other two compounds (VOLFOR and WEFSIJ) contain this moiety but with a very different conformation. Also the P atom and four F atoms of the [PF6]− anion lie on a mirror plane but shifted by 1/2 along c in respect to the mirror plane containing the thiolate ligand and the mercury atom.

XERJUZ: tris(μ
3-sulfido)-bis(2,2′-bipyridine)-iodo-oxo-tri-copper-molybdenum
First, we note that the coordinates of the carbon atoms belonging to the 2,2′-bipyridine molecule are not reported in the original paper or in the CSD file, then our analysis will be inevitably limited, we also note that this compound together with XERJOT (space group P21/n) were studied for their nonlinear optical properties (in solution).

XERJUZ was reported  in the non-centrosymmetric space group P21 (No. 4), Z
=2, but it is better described in the centrosymmetric space group P21/m (No. 11), Z
=2. Shifting all the atoms by Δy
=−0.4245 places the I(1), Mo(1), Cu(3), S(1) and O(1) atoms on the mirror plane perpendicular to b. The nest-shape molecule [MoOS3Cu3I(Phen)2] are at Wyckoff 2(e) positions, with mirror symmetry. Fig. 2 of the original paper reveals that also the 2,2′-bipyridine molecules are related by this mirror plane. The original authors say: ‘Compared with the cluster [MoI(bPy)
2][MoOS
3
Cu
3
I
2
(bPy) ] (XERJOT), the six S(O)–Mo–S bond angles of the cluster show much greater difference ranging from 106.5(3) to 115.6(6)°’, now in P21/m they range from 106.5° to 111.48°. Moreover, the difference noted by the original authors between the Cu(1)–N and Cu(2)–N bond lengths is no more present in P21/m.

XUQMAX: catena-(tris(μ
2-1,2-bis(1,2,3,4-tetrazol-2-yl)ethane-N,N′)-zinc(II) diperchlorate
This polymeric compound, collected at 100 K, was described  in the non-centrosymmetric space group P3c1 (No. 158), Z
=2, but is better described in the centrosymmetric space group 

P


3


¯


c
1

 (No. 165). In fact, after reorientation and origin shifts the Zn(II) ion is placed at the origin of the unit cell with the other atoms paired as (x,
y,
z); (−x,−y,−z). The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=−x
+1/3, y′=−y
−1/3, z′=
z
−0.2012. The averaged centrosymmetric structure leads to more reasonable distances, the equivalent distances N(1)–C(1)=1.376 and N(5)–C(2)=1.261 become N(1)–C(1)=1.318 Å, N(4)–C(1)=1.331 and N(8)–C(2)=1.363 become N(4)–C(1)=1.346 Å. We note that the free ligand, 1,2-bis(tetrazol-2-yl)ethane (Refcode=XUQLUQ), crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P21/n (No. 14) with distances N(1)–C(1)=1.328 and N(4)–C(1)=1.348 Å, very near to those of the ligand bonded to Zn(II) ion.

</mml:math>, and [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0] define a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>-centred cell with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>16.230, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>22.942, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.078 Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>89.97°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>112.66°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90.01°, space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (No. 12), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3334, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0547, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3162. The two purportedly independent Ni(II) complexes lie on the mirror plane perpendicular to b, and are related by a twofold axis and, of course, by a centre of symmetry. The two independent chlorobenzene molecule lie on twofold axes. The C<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>-fullerene molecule lies at Wyckoff position 2(c) (symmetry 2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>), thus the number of independent atoms should be reduced at ca. 1/4, however, the molecule is disordered (as reported by the original authors) and also deformed by the refinement in a non-centrosymmetric space group, the result is that many pentagons and hexagons are not correctly closed. This situation makes impossible to symmetrize the molecule and to find the correct connectivity. Thus the C<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>-fullerene coordinates were introduced in the ABOSUF.CIF file at the best that is possible to do, but attention the connectivity is still wrong(<ce:bold>!</ce:bold>). Further refinement is clearly necessary. The bond lengths are noteworthy improved on going from <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1 to <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>, for example the Ni–N distances range from 1.88 to 2.02 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1 but from 1.93 to 1.95 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (the accepted Ni–N distances in Ni(II)–porphyrinates is 1.943 Å). Similarly, the C–N distances in the pyrrole rings range from 1.26 to 1.46 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>1, but from 1.36 to 1.40 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic> 2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>.</ce:para>

Category C: change in Laue group and add a centre of symmetry
ABOSUF: (2,3,7,8,12,13,17,18-octaethylporphyrinato-N,N′,N″,N‴)-nickel(II), C60-fullerene, chlorobenzene solvate
This structure was described  in space group P1 (No. 1), Z
=1. The Niggli matrix points to lattice character No. 14 (mC) and the vectors [101],

[
1

0



1


¯


]

, and [010] define a C-centred cell with a′=16.230, b′=22.942, c′=14.078 Å, α′=89.97°, β′=112.66°, γ′=90.01°, space group C2/m (No. 12), Z
=2. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=0.5x
+0.5y
−0.3334, y′=0.5x
−0.5y
−0.0547, z′=
y
−0.3162. The two purportedly independent Ni(II) complexes lie on the mirror plane perpendicular to b, and are related by a twofold axis and, of course, by a centre of symmetry. The two independent chlorobenzene molecule lie on twofold axes. The C60-fullerene molecule lies at Wyckoff position 2(c) (symmetry 2/m), thus the number of independent atoms should be reduced at ca. 1/4, however, the molecule is disordered (as reported by the original authors) and also deformed by the refinement in a non-centrosymmetric space group, the result is that many pentagons and hexagons are not correctly closed. This situation makes impossible to symmetrize the molecule and to find the correct connectivity. Thus the C60-fullerene coordinates were introduced in the ABOSUF.CIF file at the best that is possible to do, but attention the connectivity is still wrong(!). Further refinement is clearly necessary. The bond lengths are noteworthy improved on going from P1 to C2/m, for example the Ni–N distances range from 1.88 to 2.02 Å in P1 but from 1.93 to 1.95 Å in C2/m (the accepted Ni–N distances in Ni(II)–porphyrinates is 1.943 Å). Similarly, the C–N distances in the pyrrole rings range from 1.26 to 1.46 Å in P1, but from 1.36 to 1.40 Å in C 2/m.

elements.clean_text:
Category D: add a centre of symmetry and systematic absences
BUSJII: diaqua-bis(μ
2-nicotinato N-oxide)-copper (II) tetrahydrate
This polymeric compound was reported  in space group P21 (No. 4), Z
=2, no molecular symmetry is required. However, there is a centre of symmetry nearly coincident with the Cu(II) ion. Thus, shifting the origin on the Cu(II) ion and averaging over symmetry related atoms the space group P21/n (No. 14), Z
=2, can be obtained. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−0.2466, y′=
y
−0.6528, z′=
z
−0.2588. The reflection condition ‘h0l absent for h

+

l odd’ was not recognized. The R
shelx
=7.13% is relatively high, but this can be due also to the release of water during data collection and the consequent decay of the crystal. However, convincing evidence of this space group change comes from the improvement of the molecular geometry. In fact, the C–C distances in the pyridine ring range from 1.25 to 1.47 Å in P21, but they range from 1.36 to 1.42 Å in P21/n. Similarly, N–C distances from 1.26 to 1.43 now from 1.34 to 1.38 Å. Another proof comes from the NICTCU structure, here the nicotinato N-oxide ligand is coordinated to Cu(II) in a similar manner, and shows a molecular geometry very similar to that of revised BUSJII.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. After an origin shift of 0.5000 in <ce:italic>x</ce:italic> and 0.5000 in <ce:italic>y</ce:italic> (no reorientation of cell axes), the centrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>Cmcm</ce:italic> (No. 63) is reached. This change implies the additional reflection condition ‘<ce:italic>h0l</ce:italic> absent for <ce:italic>l</ce:italic> odd’. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5000, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5000, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. In the new description the Pt atom, the 2,6-dimethylpyridine and the ethylene molecule are placed on the mirror plane perpendicular to a, while the Cl(1)–Pt–Cl(2) line is exactly perpendicular to this mirror plane. The new space group requires that the angle <ce:italic>ϕ</ce:italic> between the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C axis of ethylene and the plane of the square planar coordination become exactly 90°, while in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>222<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> this angle is 72.2°. As is known the most stable conformation requires <ce:italic>ϕ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>90°, even if the barrier of rotation of the olefin about the Pt–M axis (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>midpoint of the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C bond) is only 40–70 kJ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. Moreover, the space group change has only slightly reduced the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C bond length from 1.495 to 1.435 Å. For studying these problems we have collected from the literature the three more similar compounds: <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[PtCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(η-C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(4-cyanopyridine)] (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>CNPEPT), <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[PtCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(η-C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(2,4,6-trimethylpyridine)] (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>EYTMPT10) and <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[PtCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(η-C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(4-methylpyridine)] (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MPEYPT and MPEYPT11). The <ce:italic>ϕ</ce:italic> angles are (in the same order): 85.3°, 89.2°, 85.4° and 86.4°, while the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C distances are (in the same order): 1.35, 1.36, 1.32 and 1.39 Å. elements.clean_text:
CETYPT: trans-dichloro-(η-ethylene)-(2,6-dimethyl pyridine) platinum(II)
This structure was originally described  in the non-centrosymmetric space group C2221 (No. 20), Z
=4. After an origin shift of 0.5000 in x and 0.5000 in y (no reorientation of cell axes), the centrosymmetric space group Cmcm (No. 63) is reached. This change implies the additional reflection condition ‘h0l absent for l odd’. The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−0.5000, y′=
y
−0.5000, z′=
z. In the new description the Pt atom, the 2,6-dimethylpyridine and the ethylene molecule are placed on the mirror plane perpendicular to a, while the Cl(1)–Pt–Cl(2) line is exactly perpendicular to this mirror plane. The new space group requires that the angle ϕ between the CC axis of ethylene and the plane of the square planar coordination become exactly 90°, while in C2221 this angle is 72.2°. As is known the most stable conformation requires ϕ
=90°, even if the barrier of rotation of the olefin about the Pt–M axis (M=midpoint of the CC bond) is only 40–70 kJmol−1
. Moreover, the space group change has only slightly reduced the CC bond length from 1.495 to 1.435 Å. For studying these problems we have collected from the literature the three more similar compounds: trans-[PtCl2(η-C2H4)(4-cyanopyridine)] (Refcode=CNPEPT), trans-[PtCl2(η-C2H4)(2,4,6-trimethylpyridine)] (Refcode=EYTMPT10) and trans-[PtCl2(η-C2H4)(4-methylpyridine)] (Refcode=MPEYPT and MPEYPT11). The ϕ angles are (in the same order): 85.3°, 89.2°, 85.4° and 86.4°, while the CC distances are (in the same order): 1.35, 1.36, 1.32 and 1.39 Å. From this it is clear that the angle ϕ may be only slightly different from 90°, even if the most stable conformation requires ϕ
=90°, and the length of the ethylenic CC double bond is too high both in C2221 and in Cmcm. We note that the original authors remark ‘the structure of trans-[PtCl
2(η-C
2
H
4
)(2 6-dimethylpyridine)] compares strictly with that of trans-[PtCl
2(η-C
2
H
4
)(2,4,6-trimethylpyridine)]… The more significant difference between the two structures concerns the arrangement of the ethylene which is strongly tilted in the present case.’

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Since we have demonstrated that the tilting and the lengthening of the ethylene molecule is an artefact introduced by the refinement in the wrong space group, a new refinement in <ce:italic>Cmcm</ce:italic> should be necessary to determine a more precise structure of the ethylene molecule.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Since we have demonstrated that the tilting and the lengthening of the ethylene molecule is an artefact introduced by the refinement in the wrong space group, a new refinement in Cmcm should be necessary to determine a more precise structure of the ethylene molecule.

<ce:section-title>GOHTUS: bis(4-chloro-1,2-benzoquinone 2-oximato-N,O)-bis(imidazole-N)-copper(II)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of this compound was described  as monoclinic, space group <ce:italic>Pc</ce:italic> (No. 7), with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11.092(5), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.324(3), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11.797(4), <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>108.093(5), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, but is better described in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> (No. 14). Cell parameters and space group not reported in the original paper but supplied by CSD. However, there is no doubt that the compound was refined in space group <ce:italic>Pc</ce:italic> rather than <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, because Table III of the original work reports the bond parameters of the whole molecule and not of half a molecule as is needed in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. Moreover, the original authors have used the equivalent positions of <ce:italic>Pc</ce:italic> for calculating some bond parameters reported at page 122. However, the coordinate transformations <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3460, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2500, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.2290 lead to coordinates that are consistent with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. The reflection condition ‘<ce:italic>0k0</ce:italic> absent for <ce:italic>k</ce:italic> odd’ was not recognized. In the new description Cu(II) lies on a centre of symmetry [Wyckoff position 2(d)]. There is a distinct improvement in the molecular geometry. For example the N–C bond distances in the imidazole ligand ranged from 1.27 to 1.45 Å in <ce:italic>Pc</ce:italic> model, now in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> model they are at 1.32, 1.39, 1.34, 1.37 Å, in accordance with the accepted N–C bond lengths in imidazole coordinated to a Cu(II) ion: 1.324, 1.381, 1.340, 1.369 Å. Similarly, the geometry of the 4-chloro-1,2-benzoquinone 2-oximato ligand is improved as can be deduced from the other four structures published by the same Castellani group and containing this ligand bonded to a Cu(II) ion (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>CUHXOS, GASVAX, GOHTIG, KABJEC). The two N–O distances 1.18(1) and 1.31(1) become 1.25 Å (mean of the four structures<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.25 Å), the two C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O distances 1.17(1) and 1.34(1) Å become 1.25 Å (mean of the four structures<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.26 Å), the four C–C distances, formally double bonds, in the two benzoquinone rings 1.55–1.33, 1.45–1.27 Å become 1.44 and 1.35 Å (mean of the four structures<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.41 and 1.36 Å, respectively).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
GOHTUS: bis(4-chloro-1,2-benzoquinone 2-oximato-N,O)-bis(imidazole-N)-copper(II)
The structure of this compound was described  as monoclinic, space group Pc (No. 7), with a
=11.092(5), b
=8.324(3), c
=11.797(4), β
=108.093(5), Z
=2, but is better described in space group P21/c (No. 14). Cell parameters and space group not reported in the original paper but supplied by CSD. However, there is no doubt that the compound was refined in space group Pc rather than P21/c, because Table III of the original work reports the bond parameters of the whole molecule and not of half a molecule as is needed in P21/c. Moreover, the original authors have used the equivalent positions of Pc for calculating some bond parameters reported at page 122. However, the coordinate transformations x′=
x
−0.3460, y′=
y
−0.2500, z′=
z
−0.2290 lead to coordinates that are consistent with space group P21/c. The reflection condition ‘0k0 absent for k odd’ was not recognized. In the new description Cu(II) lies on a centre of symmetry [Wyckoff position 2(d)]. There is a distinct improvement in the molecular geometry. For example the N–C bond distances in the imidazole ligand ranged from 1.27 to 1.45 Å in Pc model, now in P21/c model they are at 1.32, 1.39, 1.34, 1.37 Å, in accordance with the accepted N–C bond lengths in imidazole coordinated to a Cu(II) ion: 1.324, 1.381, 1.340, 1.369 Å. Similarly, the geometry of the 4-chloro-1,2-benzoquinone 2-oximato ligand is improved as can be deduced from the other four structures published by the same Castellani group and containing this ligand bonded to a Cu(II) ion (Refcode=CUHXOS, GASVAX, GOHTIG, KABJEC). The two N–O distances 1.18(1) and 1.31(1) become 1.25 Å (mean of the four structures=1.25 Å), the two CO distances 1.17(1) and 1.34(1) Å become 1.25 Å (mean of the four structures=1.26 Å), the four C–C distances, formally double bonds, in the two benzoquinone rings 1.55–1.33, 1.45–1.27 Å become 1.44 and 1.35 Å (mean of the four structures=1.41 and 1.36 Å, respectively).

<ce:para view="all">This is an example where the incorrect space group could be detected studying the analogous known structures.</ce:para><ce:section-title>GUPZOG: bis(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolato)-tetrakis(trimethylphosphine)-nickel (II)-di-silver (I)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This compound was reported  in space group <ce:italic>Pn</ce:italic> (No. 7), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, no molecular symmetry is required. The coordinates can be translated so that the Ni(II) ion is located on the origin of the unit cell with space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (No. 14). The corresponding coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.74110, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.24988, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.34890. The reflection condition ‘<ce:italic>0k0</ce:italic> absent for <ce:italic>k</ce:italic> odd’ was missed. In the new description the whole molecule become exactly centrosymmetric rather than approximately centrosymmetric. As is usual when the centre of symmetry goes unrecognized, the spread of equivalent distances is considerable, for example the P–CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> distances ranged from 1.71(2) to 1.91(3) Å, now in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> they range from 1.79 to 1.82 Å (accepted P–CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> distance in trimethylphosphine bonded to a metal ion<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.824 Å). Similarly, the two C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C double bond distances in the ethylenedithiolato ligands, are 1.26(3) and 1.43(3) Å in <ce:italic>Pn</ce:italic>, this distance become 1.35 Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (accepted C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>C distance in chelating dithiolates<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.352 Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
This is an example where the incorrect space group could be detected studying the analogous known structures.
GUPZOG: bis(μ
2-1,2-dicyano-1,2-ethylenedithiolato)-tetrakis(trimethylphosphine)-nickel (II)-di-silver (I)
This compound was reported  in space group Pn (No. 7), Z
=2, no molecular symmetry is required. The coordinates can be translated so that the Ni(II) ion is located on the origin of the unit cell with space group P21/n (No. 14). The corresponding coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−0.74110, y′=
y
−0.24988, z′=
z
−0.34890. The reflection condition ‘0k0 absent for k odd’ was missed. In the new description the whole molecule become exactly centrosymmetric rather than approximately centrosymmetric. As is usual when the centre of symmetry goes unrecognized, the spread of equivalent distances is considerable, for example the P–CH3 distances ranged from 1.71(2) to 1.91(3) Å, now in P21/n they range from 1.79 to 1.82 Å (accepted P–CH3 distance in trimethylphosphine bonded to a metal ion=1.824 Å). Similarly, the two CC double bond distances in the ethylenedithiolato ligands, are 1.26(3) and 1.43(3) Å in Pn, this distance become 1.35 Å in P21/n (accepted CC distance in chelating dithiolates=1.352 Å).

However, this leads to same problem on the occupancy of the nitrogen atom of the [NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion or NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecule. In fact, for maintaining the previous formula unit, namely [(18-crown-6)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, [(18-crown-6)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)], [TlI<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, the site occupation factor of N(1) must be reduced to half of its normal value. Since this situation was not recognized during the original refinement, very high thermal factors for N(1) atom should be observed. In order to verify this we have obtained the CIF file (Document No. CSD 410098) from the Fachininformationszentrum (Karlsruhe) and have observed that the <ce:italic>Uij</ce:italic> thermal factors of N(1) atom are: <ce:italic>U</ce:italic>11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

Thus, another explanation must be advanced: the second site is populated (at least partially) by a neutral NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecule. The 18-crown-6 ether displays now exact D

3d

x,−y,−
z), with a short contact N(1)⋯N(1)′=2.873 Å, that suggests a possible hydrogen bond [NH4]+⋯NH3. However, this leads to same problem on the occupancy of the nitrogen atom of the [NH4]+ ion or NH3 molecule. In fact, for maintaining the previous formula unit, namely [(18-crown-6)(NH4)]+, [(18-crown-6)(NH3)], [TlI4]−, the site occupation factor of N(1) must be reduced to half of its normal value. Since this situation was not recognized during the original refinement, very high thermal factors for N(1) atom should be observed. In order to verify this we have obtained the CIF file (Document No. CSD 410098) from the Fachininformationszentrum (Karlsruhe) and have observed that the Uij thermal factors of N(1) atom are: U11=
U22=

 become isomorphous with the compounds H[FeBr4(18-crown-6)2(H2O)

NH


4

 or NH3 cannot change the space group of the bulky structure, it is possible that the nitrogen atoms is disordered in many site of the large cavities present in this compound. <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2. The two [C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>As]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations or the two [CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions are related by the same centre of symmetry, thus after shifting the origin on this centre the atomic coordinates can be averaged according to space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>. The coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/4, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0982, z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/4. Although, the <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>

For example, the C–C distances in the benzene ring range from 1.24 to 1.56 Å in the <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2 model, but from 1.37 to 1.44 Å in the <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> model. The four As–C distances in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2 are 1.83, 1.95, 1.88 and 1.96 Å, while in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> they are 1.89 and 1.92 Å (accepted As–Car in [Ph<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>As]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation is 1.905 Å). Similarly, for the <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) in the approximate trigonal bipyramidal [CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) equatorial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.411(18) and 2.273(18) Å and <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) axial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.419(17) and 2.492(16) Å in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2, while in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> they are: <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) equatorial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.33 Å and <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) axial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.45 Å. We have found only one compound (Refcode<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>HUBNEX) containing the [CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, the averaged distances are <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl)n–Cl) equatorial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.349 and 2.319 Å and <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(Sn–Cl) axial<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.486 and 2.455 Å. elements.clean_text:
PASMSN: tetraphenylarsonium methyltetrachlorotin (IV)
The structure of this compound was reported  in the non-centrosymmetric space group P2 (No. 3), Z
=2, but is better described in the centrosymmetric space group P2/n (No.13), Z
=2. The two [C24H20As]+ cations or the two [CH3SnCl4]− anions are related by the same centre of symmetry, thus after shifting the origin on this centre the atomic coordinates can be averaged according to space group P2/n. The coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−1/4, y′=
y
−0.0982, z=
z′−1/4. Although, the R
shelx
=9.74% is relatively high we are sure that this space group change is necessary because there is a distinct improvement in the geometry on going from P2 to P2/n. For example, the C–C distances in the benzene ring range from 1.24 to 1.56 Å in the P2 model, but from 1.37 to 1.44 Å in the P2/n model. The four As–C distances in P2 are 1.83, 1.95, 1.88 and 1.96 Å, while in P2/n they are 1.89 and 1.92 Å (accepted As–Car in [Ph4As]+ cation is 1.905 Å). Similarly, for the d(Sn–Cl) in the approximate trigonal bipyramidal [CH3SnCl4]− anion, d(Sn–Cl) equatorial=2.411(18) and 2.273(18) Å and d(Sn–Cl) axial=2.419(17) and 2.492(16) Å in P2, while in P2/n they are: d(Sn–Cl) equatorial=2.33 Å and d(Sn–Cl) axial=2.45 Å. We have found only one compound (Refcode=HUBNEX) containing the [CH3SnCl4]− anion, the averaged distances are d(Sn–Cl)n–Cl) equatorial=2.349 and 2.319 Å and d(Sn–Cl) axial=2.486 and 2.455 Å. This space group change implies the additional reflection condition ‘h0l absent for h

+

l odd’. The original authors report” the h0l zone shows an approximate (non-space group) absence for h

+

l

=

2n+1 and the projection (

) shows a view with considerable pseudo symmetry (compare with space group P42
/n (No. 86) with the tetragonal c(axis)

=

2b)” . Then the original authors have noted the n-glide and the relative extintions and have suggested space group P42/n, probably for maintaining the cell origin on a binary axis, while  clearly suggest a centre of symmetry at x
=1/4 and z
=1/4. Moreover, the original authors say: ” The distribution of normalized structure factors (E’s) clearly pointed to a non-centrosymmetric space group…”, however, it is well known that such tests can be very deceptive when heavy atoms are present  or when a significant number of weak reflections has been deleted as is usual in film techniques .

2-formato-O,O′)-thallium(I))
This polymeric structure was described  in the non-centrosymmetric space group Pna21 (No. 33), Z
=4, but can be transformed to the centrosymmetric space group Pnna (No. 52), Z
=4. After reorientation, transformation matrix

, and an origin shift of −0.2556 in x and 0.2500 in z, the O(1) and O(2) atoms of the formate ion are paired (shift=0.226 Å), the Tl atom is moved on the twofold axis along c (shift=0.000) and the C–H bond become coincident with the twofold axis along a (carbon shift=0.0755 Å). The reflection condition ‘h0l absent for h

+

l odd’ was not recorded, in the old setting this condition is ‘hk0 absent for h+k odd’. The two C–O bonds, which are 1.258(5) and 1.260(5) Å in Pna21, become 1.225 Å in Pnna, because they are now crystallographically equivalent. This shortening is expected by the original authors when they say: ‘It appears thus that the C–O(1) and C–O(2) bonds are significantly longer in TlHCOO than the C–O bonds in the other formates, where they range between 1.232(7) and 1.242(1)Å’. However, the O–C–O angle, which is 125.4(2)° in Pna21, become 130.1(2)° in Pnna, a too large value in comparison to other formates, even if the anti-anti bonding mode of the present formate might enlarge the O–C–O angle. However, further refinement in the correct space group is needed for a better description of this formate ion.

In fact, the coordinate transformations x′=−x, y′=−y, z′=
z
−0.2500 lead to space group Pnma.

In the new space group all the terpy ligand, V(1) and O(1) atoms lie on the mirror plane at y
=3/4, while Mo, O(4) and O(5) atoms lie on the mirror plane at y
=1/4, only the O(2) atom is in general position. This space group change implies the additional reflection conditions ‘0kl absent for k

+

l odd’ and ‘hk0 absent for h odd’. We cannot check directly these conditions for the unavailability of S.F. tables but a S.F. calculation reveals that these reflections are indeed very weak. The molecular geometry is practically unchanged because there is only one atomic pair, O(2)–O(3), with original distances Mo(1)–O(2)=1.794 and Mo(1)–O(3)=1.791 Å, in Pnma Mo(1)–O(2)=1.792 Å.

<ce:section-title>YEQDAZ: <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-(1,4,8,11-tetra-azacyclotetradecane-1-(hydrogen methylphosphonato)-8-(methylphosphonato)-N,N′,N′′,N′′′,O,O′)-cobalt(III) hydrate</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This structure was reported  in space group <ce:italic>Pn</ce:italic> (No. 7), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4. The corresponding atoms of the two purportedly independent Co(III) complexes and the water molecules O(13)–O(17) and O(15)–O(19) are related by a centre of symmetry, while the O(14)–O(18) water pair is related by a second centre of symmetry. The water molecules O(16) is not paired and thus was not considered in the present analysis, also because the addition of a centre of symmetry produces an O(16)′ oxygen atom with an unrealistic distance O(16)–O(16)′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.834(7) Å, that is too short also for an hydrogen bond. After the origin is shifted on the first centre of symmetry, the space group becomes <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (No. 14). The coordinate transformations are: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.4986, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/4, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5005. The reflection condition ‘<ce:italic>0k0</ce:italic> absent for <ce:italic>k</ce:italic> odd’ was missed. Although, the shifts are as expected when the centre of symmetry goes unrecognized the molecular geometry of the Co(III) complexes is not greatly affected by the omission of the centre of symmetry, this is a consequence of the similarity of the two purportedly independent molecules, in fact, the original authors say” <ce:italic>the bond lengths for both the units are virtually the same within the</ce:italic> 3<ce:italic>σ interval.</ce:italic>”. This is probably due to the low temperature (150 K) used during data collection. However, in the revised structure there are four CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> distances of the two –N–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–N– arms that are still too short: 1.497, 1.478, 1.479, 1.485 Å. In fact, the same distances found in the two similar compounds YEQCUS and QEXZEY studied by the same original authors are slightly longer (mean 1.523 Å), thus a refinement in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, with the same reflections already collected, is necessary to check these distances.</ce:para>

YEQDAZ: cis-(1,4,8,11-tetra-azacyclotetradecane-1-(hydrogen methylphosphonato)-8-(methylphosphonato)-N,N′,N′′,N′′′,O,O′)-cobalt(III) hydrate
This structure was reported  in space group Pn (No. 7), Z
=4. The corresponding atoms of the two purportedly independent Co(III) complexes and the water molecules O(13)–O(17) and O(15)–O(19) are related by a centre of symmetry, while the O(14)–O(18) water pair is related by a second centre of symmetry. The water molecules O(16) is not paired and thus was not considered in the present analysis, also because the addition of a centre of symmetry produces an O(16)′ oxygen atom with an unrealistic distance O(16)–O(16)′=1.834(7) Å, that is too short also for an hydrogen bond. After the origin is shifted on the first centre of symmetry, the space group becomes P21/n (No. 14). The coordinate transformations are: x′=
x
−0.4986, y′=
y
−3/4, z′=
z
−0.5005. The reflection condition ‘0k0 absent for k odd’ was missed. Although, the shifts are as expected when the centre of symmetry goes unrecognized the molecular geometry of the Co(III) complexes is not greatly affected by the omission of the centre of symmetry, this is a consequence of the similarity of the two purportedly independent molecules, in fact, the original authors say” the bond lengths for both the units are virtually the same within the 3σ interval.”. This is probably due to the low temperature (150 K) used during data collection. However, in the revised structure there are four CH2–CH2 distances of the two –N–CH2–CH2–CH2–N– arms that are still too short: 1.497, 1.478, 1.479, 1.485 Å. In fact, the same distances found in the two similar compounds YEQCUS and QEXZEY studied by the same original authors are slightly longer (mean 1.523 Å), thus a refinement in P21/n, with the same reflections already collected, is necessary to check these distances.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Category E: structures with non-space group translations (NSGT)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">NSGT means that the structure has been published with a cell and a space group that does not describe the real translations present in the crystal. We report here only two examples (XETVOH and XEYHAK) but other 44 examples might be present in ICA.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Category E: structures with non-space group translations (NSGT)
NSGT means that the structure has been published with a cell and a space group that does not describe the real translations present in the crystal. We report here only two examples (XETVOH and XEYHAK) but other 44 examples might be present in ICA.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>XETVOH: bis(2-(4-pyridyl)-4,6-(4-pyridinium)tryazine)<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>-octamolybdate dihydrate</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of this compound was described  in space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (No. 14), <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, using the unit formula reported by us: 2[C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, 2(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O). However, the atomic coordinates of chemically equivalent atoms are nearly related, but not within the s.u., by the apparently fortuitous relation (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>), that is a mirror plane at <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 in space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (No. 12), while the O(12) and O(13) atoms bonded to Mo(4) are related by the relation (−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>), that is a twofold axis in <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>. In fact, without origin shifts or reorientation of cell axes it is possible to describe this structure in space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (No. 12) with the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion having crystallographic imposed 2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> symmetry and the organic cation [C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> having crystallographic imposed <ce:italic>m</ce:italic> symmetry. The water molecule deviates from the mirror plane by 0.11 Å but we have forced it to lie on the added mirror plane, in fact, this small molecule usually does not respect completely the symmetry of the bulky groups. The <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">shelx</ce:inf> (2.16%) is very low and leads to change this space group even if the shifts needed to achieve the higher symmetry are 10–12 times greater than the corresponding s.u. In fact, during the refinement in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, even if this space group is centrosymmetric, there are correlations between the positional parameters of the atoms related by the lost mirror plane, especially between the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> coordinates. XETVOH: bis(2-(4-pyridyl)-4,6-(4-pyridinium)tryazine)δ-octamolybdate dihydrate
The structure of this compound was described  in space group P21/n (No. 14), Z
=2, using the unit formula reported by us: 2[C18H14N6]2+, [Mo8O26]4−, 2(H2O). However, the atomic coordinates of chemically equivalent atoms are nearly related, but not within the s.u., by the apparently fortuitous relation (x, 1−
y, z), that is a mirror plane at y
=1/2 in space group I2/m (No. 12), while the O(12) and O(13) atoms bonded to Mo(4) are related by the relation (−x, y, −z), that is a twofold axis in I2/m. In fact, without origin shifts or reorientation of cell axes it is possible to describe this structure in space group I2/m (No. 12) with the [Mo8O26]4− anion having crystallographic imposed 2/m symmetry and the organic cation [C18H14N6]2+ having crystallographic imposed m symmetry. The water molecule deviates from the mirror plane by 0.11 Å but we have forced it to lie on the added mirror plane, in fact, this small molecule usually does not respect completely the symmetry of the bulky groups. The R
shelx (2.16%) is very low and leads to change this space group even if the shifts needed to achieve the higher symmetry are 10–12 times greater than the corresponding s.u. In fact, during the refinement in P21/n, even if this space group is centrosymmetric, there are correlations between the positional parameters of the atoms related by the lost mirror plane, especially between the z coordinates. However, the new space group I2/m requires the additional reflection condition ’hkl absent for h

+

k

+

l odd’.

Also Cu(II) lies on a centre of symmetry, as in <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, but in addition on the twofold axis along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> (Wyckoff position 2(d), symmetry 2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>). As a consequence the two organic ligands bonded to Cu(II) are related not only by a centre of symmetry but also by a twofold axis. The bond distances are not substantially varied, but the interesting Cu(II)–O(1) and Cu(II)–O(2) distances require a particular discussion because the O(1) and O(2) atoms are only roughly related by the mirror plane of <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>, in fact, the atomic shift for O(1)–O(2) pair is 0.50 Å. The original authors report Cu(II)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.405 and Cu(II)–O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.950 Å, and explain this difference saying ‘<ce:italic>the geometry may be described as 4</ce:italic>

We also agree with the importance of the Janh–Teller distortions in the stereochemistry of the Cu(II) ion, but it is impossible in this moment, without the S.F. tables at hand, to predict how much this difference is due to Jahn–Teller distortions and how much is due to correlation effects. Hoping to solve this problem, we have searched all the structures with a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] moiety (N= nitrogen atom capable to form a strong bond with Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>). Excluding DUDSIE (a parent compound of XEYHAK) because its long Cu(II)–N bond (2.357 Å) can change the molecular geometry, we have collected 12 structures. The four Cu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bond are usually in the range 2.00–2.40 Å, however, in AMADCU they are all equal to 2.161 Å, while in ZZZFQQ11 the range is very large from 1.955 to 2.496 Å. Although, the Cu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.950 Å found in XEYHAK is the shortest distance up to now reported, we can say that the Cu–OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> distances of XEYHAK are acceptable and really the O(1) and O(2) atoms are disordered across the mirror plane. For this reason we have introduced in the XEYHAK.CIF file the O(1) and O(2) coordinates transformed as before reported but not averaged across the mirror plane, the site occupation factors are thus imposed as 0.500 for both the oxygen atoms.</ce:para>

XEYHAK: catena-((μ
2-2,4-bis(dicyanomethylene)cyclobutane-1,3-dione-N,N′)-tetra-aqua-copper(II))
Firstly we note that the space group reported in the original publication  is P21/n (No. 14) while the space group reported in the CSD file is P21/c (No. 14). We have used the latter space group because P 21/n leads to very short contacts between the water molecules and the carbon atoms of the organic ligand. This structure can be transformed to C2/m (No. 12) using the coordinate transformations: x′=
z, y′=−y, z′=
x. The 2,4-bis(dicyanomethylene)cyclobutane-1,3-dione ligand, which has 



1


¯



 symmetry in the original description, is now located at Wyckoff position 2(a) (symmetry 2/m) and becomes exactly planar and coincident with the mirror plane of C2/m. Also Cu(II) lies on a centre of symmetry, as in P21/c, but in addition on the twofold axis along b (Wyckoff position 2(d), symmetry 2/m). As a consequence the two organic ligands bonded to Cu(II) are related not only by a centre of symmetry but also by a twofold axis. The bond distances are not substantially varied, but the interesting Cu(II)–O(1) and Cu(II)–O(2) distances require a particular discussion because the O(1) and O(2) atoms are only roughly related by the mirror plane of C2/m, in fact, the atomic shift for O(1)–O(2) pair is 0.50 Å. The original authors report Cu(II)–O(1)=2.405 and Cu(II)–O(2)=1.950 Å, and explain this difference saying ‘the geometry may be described as 4

+

2, which is classical for a copper(II) ion in an elongated octahedral coordination.’. We also agree with the importance of the Janh–Teller distortions in the stereochemistry of the Cu(II) ion, but it is impossible in this moment, without the S.F. tables at hand, to predict how much this difference is due to Jahn–Teller distortions and how much is due to correlation effects. Hoping to solve this problem, we have searched all the structures with a trans-[Cu(H2O)4N2] moiety (N= nitrogen atom capable to form a strong bond with Cu2+). Excluding DUDSIE (a parent compound of XEYHAK) because its long Cu(II)–N bond (2.357 Å) can change the molecular geometry, we have collected 12 structures. The four Cu–OH2 bond are usually in the range 2.00–2.40 Å, however, in AMADCU they are all equal to 2.161 Å, while in ZZZFQQ11 the range is very large from 1.955 to 2.496 Å. Although, the Cu–OH2
=1.950 Å found in XEYHAK is the shortest distance up to now reported, we can say that the Cu–OH2 distances of XEYHAK are acceptable and really the O(1) and O(2) atoms are disordered across the mirror plane. For this reason we have introduced in the XEYHAK.CIF file the O(1) and O(2) coordinates transformed as before reported but not averaged across the mirror plane, the site occupation factors are thus imposed as 0.500 for both the oxygen atoms.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Discussion and conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Fortunately category A errors (increases in Laue symmetry) produces only small (∼0.02–0.05 Å) distortions of the molecular geometry, but two important errors can be introduced with this category:<ce:list>
<ce:list-item>
<ce:label>(i)</ce:label>
<ce:para view="all">The incorrect attribution of polymorphism due to an incorrect space group determination. We have described here the example of SEVLIO01-SEVLIO, in this case the different experimental synthetic conditions led the original authors to believe to have synthesized a new polymorph. This type of mistake is not new and has been already reported by us .</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item>
<ce:label>(ii)</ce:label>
<ce:para view="all">The non-attribution of isomorphism due to an incorrect space group determination. We have described here six examples (ENCNBZ, LIVZUL, METHEY, BIPNAP, QARPUU, HOVQAK).</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Discussion and conclusion
Fortunately category A errors (increases in Laue symmetry) produces only small (∼0.02–0.05 Å) distortions of the molecular geometry, but two important errors can be introduced with this category:

(i)
The incorrect attribution of polymorphism due to an incorrect space group determination. We have described here the example of SEVLIO01-SEVLIO, in this case the different experimental synthetic conditions led the original authors to believe to have synthesized a new polymorph. This type of mistake is not new and has been already reported by us .


(ii)
The non-attribution of isomorphism due to an incorrect space group determination. We have described here six examples (ENCNBZ, LIVZUL, METHEY, BIPNAP, QARPUU, HOVQAK).

This type of mistake is not new and has been already reported by us .</ce:para>

For example, NIGGIT was published with the C–C bonds of the benzene rings in the range 1.06-1.66 Å, now they are reported in the normal range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The non-attribution of isomorphism due to an incorrect space group determination. We have described here six examples (ENCNBZ, LIVZUL, METHEY, BIPNAP, QARPUU, HOVQAK).
On the other hand the well known problem of effective singularity when a centrosymmetric structure is described in a non-centrosymmetric space group leads to bond lengths that may be in error of 0.2-0.3 Å or even more. For example, NIGGIT was published with the C–C bonds of the benzene rings in the range 1.06-1.66 Å, now they are reported in the normal range.

elements.clean_text:
reports atomic shifts as large as 0.226 Å (for DIYGUN and QQBKV10), but we may ask: what large may be the atomic shifts when a centre of symmetry goes unrecognized?
Marsh reports  that ignoring a centre of symmetry can result in errors in the atomic coordinates that are several times larger than the nominal e.s.d.’s, but we present now two instructive examples taken directly from the literature.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">MIZPAM was published  in space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (No. 12), but the CIF file deposited at CCDC presents space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 (No. 5) (original CIF No. CCDC-233510). Later on the original authors have deposited the correct CIF file with space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> (CIF No. CCDC-162758). The atomic shifts range from 0.000 for the Cd(1) atom to 0.253 Å for the C(4)–C(7) pair, mean shift is 0.120 Å. The molecular geometry is deformed by the near-singularities, for example the N–C distances in the pyridine ring are 1.17 and 1.45 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2, but 1.304 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/m.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: MIZPAM was published  in space group C2/m (No. 12), but the CIF file deposited at CCDC presents space group C2 (No. 5) (original CIF No. CCDC-233510). Later on the original authors have deposited the correct CIF file with space group C2/m (CIF No. CCDC-162758). The atomic shifts range from 0.000 for the Cd(1) atom to 0.253 Å for the C(4)–C(7) pair, mean shift is 0.120 Å. The molecular geometry is deformed by the near-singularities, for example the N–C distances in the pyridine ring are 1.17 and 1.45 Å in C2, but 1.304 Å in C2/m.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">GUKGAU was published  in space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> but the coordinates were deposited at CCDC in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2. CSD say: ’<ce:italic>The space group is C</ce:italic>2, <ce:italic>not C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m as reported in the paper</ce:italic>’. However, the true space group is <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic> and the molecules lies with Cu(II) and the ether oxygen donor on the mirror plane, see Fig. 3 of the original work. The atomic shifts range from 0.00 for Cu(II) ion to 0.32 Å for C(4)–C(9) pair, mean shift is 0.23 Å (excluding the perchlorate ion). The molecular geometry is greatly deformed by the near-singularities, for example the two C–O distances (O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ether oxygen donor) are 1.02 and 1.66 Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2, but 1.485(9) Å in <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: GUKGAU was published  in space group C2/m but the coordinates were deposited at CCDC in C2. CSD say: ’The space group is C2, not C2/m as reported in the paper’. However, the true space group is C2/m and the molecules lies with Cu(II) and the ether oxygen donor on the mirror plane, see Fig. 3 of the original work. The atomic shifts range from 0.00 for Cu(II) ion to 0.32 Å for C(4)–C(9) pair, mean shift is 0.23 Å (excluding the perchlorate ion). The molecular geometry is greatly deformed by the near-singularities, for example the two C–O distances (O=ether oxygen donor) are 1.02 and 1.66 Å in C2, but 1.485(9) Å in C2/m.

<ce:para view="all">As above reported NSGT means that the structure has been published with a cell and a space group that does not describe the real translations present in the crystal. NSGT can be present in two ways:<ce:list>
<ce:list-item>
<ce:label>(i)</ce:label>
<ce:para view="all">The original authors have used cell parameters that are multiple or linear combinations of multiple Bravais translations really present in the crystal. Two examples (JECREO  and COJJAM ) have already been reported by us or other authors.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item>
<ce:label>(ii)</ce:label>
<ce:para view="all">The original authors have chosen a non-primitive cell (C,I,F) but have handled it as a primitive one, but the Bravais translations are correct. One example, QUJXEY, has already been reported by us.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
As above reported NSGT means that the structure has been published with a cell and a space group that does not describe the real translations present in the crystal. NSGT can be present in two ways:

(i)
The original authors have used cell parameters that are multiple or linear combinations of multiple Bravais translations really present in the crystal. Two examples (JECREO  and COJJAM ) have already been reported by us or other authors.


(ii)
The original authors have chosen a non-primitive cell (C,I,F) but have handled it as a primitive one, but the Bravais translations are correct. One example, QUJXEY, has already been reported by us.

elements.clean_text:
The original authors have chosen a non-primitive cell (C,I,F) but have handled it as a primitive one, but the Bravais translations are correct. One example, QUJXEY, has already been reported by us.
We have discussed only two examples (XETVOH and XEYHAK) but other 44 compounds with the NSGT problem might be present in ICA. The unavailability of S.F. tables do not allow to reach a conclusive result only on the basis of atomic coordinates. The NSGT compounds usually contain a bulky complex or a metallo-organic molecule that respect the NSGT perfectly but there are also some small groups (H2O, NH3, C2H5OH, 



ClO


4




-








NO


3




-



, etc.) that are disordered across the newly added translation and/or symmetry elements, i.e., these small disordered groups generate superlattice reflections. Since it is difficult to handle these small disordered groups using only their atomic coordinates, we are constrained to report only two NSGT examples.

Marsh [Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B 60 (2004) 252–253].</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">
<ce:bold>Dore Augusto Clemente</ce:bold> was born in 1940 in Susa (Turin), Italy. He studied at the University of Padua and received his Laurea degree in Chemistry in 1966. His career began in 1966 as assistant professor of Structural Chemistry, then he joined the Radioelements Laboratory (CNR), where he worked on the crystal and molecular structure of Uranium and Technetium complexes under the supervision of Professor Ugo Croatto. In 1980, he moved to Strasbourg University (France) for working with Dr. Bernard Rees in the low-temperature crystallographic laboratory on the determination of atomic charges and experimental electron density in the bond region using diffraction methods. In 1983, he became Associate Professor and then in 1986 Full professor of General and Inorganic Chemistry. From 1986 to 1993 he served in the Faculty of Science of the University of Lecce and in 1993 he accepted an appointment in the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Trieste as Chair in Chemistry. Note added in proof
The following five structures BIPNAP, GOBHEK, LAGQEP, METBIW and NIGKAP have been corrected also in a very recent paper written by Richard E. Marsh [Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B 60 (2004) 252–253].

Dore Augusto Clemente was born in 1940 in Susa (Turin), Italy. He studied at the University of Padua and received his Laurea degree in Chemistry in 1966. His career began in 1966 as assistant professor of Structural Chemistry, then he joined the Radioelements Laboratory (CNR), where he worked on the crystal and molecular structure of Uranium and Technetium complexes under the supervision of Professor Ugo Croatto. In 1980, he moved to Strasbourg University (France) for working with Dr. Bernard Rees in the low-temperature crystallographic laboratory on the determination of atomic charges and experimental electron density in the bond region using diffraction methods. In 1983, he became Associate Professor and then in 1986 Full professor of General and Inorganic Chemistry. From 1986 to 1993 he served in the Faculty of Science of the University of Lecce and in 1993 he accepted an appointment in the Faculty of Engineering of the University of Trieste as Chair in Chemistry. His current scientific interests concern the structure of bio-metal complexes bonded to DNA fragments, the Rietveld method in the study of X-ray diffraction powder spectrum of metal oxides and finally the structures described in space groups of unnecessary low symmetry.
